SisLEeMtBzsuSq3Fp6w0ag.text: If you like mussels, you will find good ones here in the Belgium restaurant, Belgos. I like to go during the week during 'beat-the-clock' times from 5 to 6:30 p.m, where the moral of the story is that you pay for the time you arrive. There is a specific menu for this, and I always go for the Moules Mariniere Traditionnelle with frites and a glass of house white wine (all included with the price). The Green Thai mussel pot from the main menu is interesting but nevertheless, tasty. And be sure to check out their drinks list, with an extensive range of beers - I always go for the flavoured ones!The interior is interesting, I wouldn't say welcoming as such, tucked under ground level, it has an almost stiff industrial feel to it... the toilets are interesting.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom

aTReHMQ4Z9tcU1tdaHt7fA.text: I'm very much a fan of the beat the clock menu. £7 for moules frites and a cheeky beer? Yeah, sign me up!I'm very much a fan of working my way through the beer menu. Thanks Belgium! (About time you pitched in).

WA-Ov-HeA8bOXxbSJyhlGg.text: Each time I visit my relatives in London, they always take me to this restaurant. The first time I came here, I had the salmon fillet and it was delicious! The sauce on top of it was perfectly made--not too sweet and not salty, just plain savory. We also had the salmon cakes appetizers and they were so freakin' good. If I didn't want to look like a rude and greedy pig, I would've ate all of them myself. The last time here, I ordered the roast duck breast and I was just plain disappointed! I expected the texture to be like a juicy peking duck but I realized this place isn't a Chinese restaurant. The duck was slightly chewy and the plum sauce was a bit too sweet for my liking. Since my friend ordered the salmon fillet, I dipped my duck in her sauce so I can finish chowing down and move on to dessert. We all shared the creme brulee and it was decent--nothing special. For the price, I recommend getting dessert elsewhere. Also, my niece and nephew's food was free because for every adult ordering a main course, each child eats for free. Is it just me that thinks this special is super cute? Their specialties are mussels, chips, and beer. Chips were pretty good but nothing amazing. Mussels aren't my cup of tea so I can't give you my opinion but my cousins LOVE them here. Beer? I definitely have to try it next time. Overall, this place is okay... I think I would have enjoyed it more if it wasn't so expensive but hey, it's London.

fdgOImp5rovhcAVBXAQo4A.text: Very good mussels and a vast selection of beers. Great vibes.The service is fast, but the waiters are sometimes not nice, hinting that you should speed up your choice process.. Other times they are great, though, helping you out and giving good recommendations.

YHRE4vxz_M1i5SJ2axgLSg.text: Love this place. A wonderful selection of Belgian beers and some really delicious food (steak, checken, pork and especially the moules) in a brilliant cellar, not the cheapest place around though the lunch and early evening set-menus are a bargain. Highly recommended!

Ue0Mm1vbjYBr958a7Cvq5g.text: Frickin' delicious! I enjoyed a perfectly cooked half chicken in a lemon cream sauce with new potatoes and my companion had a lovely steak frites with peppercorn sauce. They also offer shots of schnapps in a wooden board called a stick. I had a 4 stick that had apple, melon, some berry type thing, and a cream liqueur. So delicious and unfortunately when I tired to go back a few days later they were fully booked! Highly recommended and the staff were great!

LKj3keAfxSrvWTDU4t6ySw.text: I had arranged a team Christmas dinner here upon recommendation by a colleague. The booking staff went out of the way to accommodate the party of 17 at fairly late notice and were prompt with offering a variety of options for those with diet restrictions. Most interestingly, we could place our orders from the Xmas set menu after reaching the venue, rather than having to pre-order the main course, which saved a lot of headache in terms of coordinating the team dinner.The bar upstairs made for a good hangout before dinner and once it was time, we were ushered quite promptly onto the benches and served a variety of schnaaps to warm us up. The waitress came around and took our orders quickly and voila, in a few minutes, we had our starters - I was clearly a Belgo novice. If I had known better, I would have gone for the Thai Green Mussels which looked like a delight even from a distance (noted for my next visit). My chicken liver parfait with cranberry and port chutney was nice but seemed somewhat underwhelming as an entry into a Christmas meal. Those who had ordered Belgian beer croquettes (with piccalilli & fried parsely) & chilled beer asparagus (with vinaigrette) seemed to have polished off their appetisers rather quickly - not sure whether it was because it was tasty or that they were served in smaller portion sizes.For mains, I had ordered the beef carbonnade, beef braised in sweet Gueuze beer with apples and plums, with a side of frites and I absolutely loved it! It was a definite score for the right blend of tender meat and sweet after-tastes. The portion size was just right, filling but it didn't leave me feeling stuffed, like Christmas meals tend to do. Another sign of me being a Belgo novice is that I did not even look at the beer menu - what was I thinking, right? I just went for a glass of the house red which paired well with the beef. Among my colleagues' orders, the half rotisserie chicken was served in generous portions, the sausage & mash looked alright but a tad on the scarce side and the salmon fillet looked like a good order too, but the winner seemed to be the moules, yet again.For dessert, I had a light dark chocolate mousse served with a coffee Anglaise and as promised, it's light and not very sweet - a satisfying even if a safe choice. Those who went for the winterberry pavlova (wth fresh cream+mulled wine coulis) seemed very happy with their choice too. I have also noted that I will want to try their Belgian waffle the next time I visit.Service was prompt and friendly and the tasty food kept me occupied enough to not mind the usual tiresome banter amongst work crowd :P At £24.95/set before service, it was a reasonably priced fare. Definitely coming back for the moules+frites!

5rDyCXAyPBCCSquQRz6Aaw.text: There a couple of Belgian chains in the UK. I think that Belgo stands out on the quality of its food. The glass bowl entrance leads to a steel staircase down and then through a hall, which deposits you in front of the long, open, and very busy kitchen. To left and right are rooms with long wooden beer hall tables. The bustle and noise is considerable: not a place for a quiet romantic rendez-vous. The food was excellent, though, if not cheap. And the beers: well, there are dozens of Balgian types, on tap or bottled, trappist to wheat to chocolate. Until the end of October 2008 they have on their Oktoberfeast deal: a three-course menu of several choices paried with specially-selected beers for each course at £27.50. Or the food alone is £19.95, letting you pick your beers. There's a minimum of 2 people required to order this menu. Not everyone in my group was convinced by their beer pairings, but I liked mine. Everyone thought the food was great: my asparagus starter was perfectly cooked, and my bowl of mussels proved meaty and delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Drink this beer!

gZymvhFerrO1RqdKc9P-vQ.text: Belgo is an excellent restaurant with great beer, delicious food and friendly service. This was perhaps the best meal I've had in my 2 weeks in Southern England and London. The Thai Curry mussels were exquisite, as well as the goat cheese starter. My meal of roasted duck breast was easily the best at the table; it was cooked perfectly on a bed of silky smooth mashed potatoes and perfectly seasoned sauce.The service at this restaurant was brilliant, renewing my faith in English customer service. It was a complete 180 degrees from your disgruntled London pub barkeep. (Who were probably annoyed with me because I was a tourist but hey, in this town who isn't?)This was actually my second time at Belgo, the first being for beer and desserts. The chocolate cheese cake is light and delicious and perfectly hits the spot. If you are interested in Belgian beer, this is definitely the place to go. For the full beer menu, you need to go downstairs to the restaurant. The small upstairs bar as a very limited menu.All in all Belgo is a great restaurant. And with plenty of room downstairs, they will have room for you on a busy Saturday night when every place else is filled to the brim.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Roasted Duck Breast

WQEmp-yH6u3ApXjFCrGm9Q.text: We went there for lunch to try their mussels with beer.A fun experience traveling down the lift to the underground dining area, their service was average, and the food was pretty good though not the best I've had, and the drinks were really nice.

aaU_CBUG-uU2KW5dEO0w_Q.text: A restaurant nestled in Covent Garden with friendly staff in weird outfits and incredible mussels!My friends and I ordered the green thai curry and provencale mussel pots, and the portuguais mussel bowl. However, the thai green curry mussels were by far the best! I count this dish as one of the two most delicious things I've had during my 4 month stay in London.The sauce was so flavorful, the best green thai curry I've ever had. I actually don't even like mussels that much because it usually ends up being too chewy, but these were cooked perfectly. Each portion comes with a Kilo of mussels, which is good enough for two people to share. It also come with a side of chips. The other flavors we ordered were good, but they weren't memorable and were clearly no match for the green thai curry ones. We only had mussels during my one time there, but looking around to the food on other tables, they all looked quite good. So, therefore, the green thai curry mussels are what compels me to give this place 5 stars! Please order this if you come here! The only downside to this place, in my experience, was that we couldn't take home our leftovers, which was a shame!

_DlrsTEuyULYkyaYtpSOwQ.text: Impressed with the lively atmosphere and modern-artsy-industrial decor! I ordered the salmon dish which was perfectly seasoned and left me fully satisfied, just enough food and no feeling of food coma.Will definitely come back after work hours to try the beer and mussels!

87zi-wl6zYvvARtyy5N0zA.text: This is splendid! Nice atmosphere, great service with a vision, savory dishes and decent prices. It won't get much better than this! The desserts and beers are just amazing.

9Iu7w9Rzeda7Up6MCcNxWA.text: I went here five years ago and I am still bragging about the place. I sent my boss there this past summer and he and his wife loved it as well. if you like mussels it is a must visit when you are in London. The beer choices are excellent, time to bee adventurous. Make reservations it gets quite busy.

sF18MGu4HsT9TPQQyjqsEg.text: This place is solid and reliable, good beers, the service is really not up to the quality of the rest of it; they are kind and try hard but need more training. Its all about process here, not people. Its inexpensive, child friendly, and a fine place to stop in if you have a lively party or just need to drink a lot of excellent belgian beer. I like the other downtown onebetter; feels a bit less like being processed for whatever reason.Nevertheless, I'm sure I'll be back and this is a neighborhood where good midrange options are hard to find unless you go Chinese.

W_oYAZp-PQvBX4TITwWrJg.text: Lobsterfest Belgo's - Pics The London Foodie (thelondonfoodie.co.uk/20… ) Just as 17 years ago when I lived in Chalk Farm and first started going to Belgo Noord, today I am still struck by the originality of the ideas introduced by this restaurant to the London food scene. Not only has it made moules frites an affordable and accessible choice, but it has also introduced a vast range of top quality Belgian beers to many Londoners. Few people were familiar with Belgian food in the UK in the early 90s; dishes like Waterzooi and Beef Carbonnade were relatively unknown, and the concept of partnering food and beer was also novel. Belgo also introduced us to the concept of cuisine a la bière where beer is used as a marinade, sauce or flavouring, and I cannot think of any other type of beer which would be more appropriate to this style of cooking. The meat in Beef Carbonnade is braised in sweet Gueuze, a sparkling sour beer, while the slow cooked shank of lamb is served with DeKoninck beer and balsamic jus. The idea of preparing and cooking mussels can be a frightening prospect, but at £12.95 for a large pot, eating moules frites is no longer a daunting or expensive affair. Belgo was also one of the first restaurants to open its kitchens to the public, when the concept of open plan kitchen was still to be adopted and popularised by other restaurant chains. The design of its restaurants is as cutting edge as when it first opened. I like the combination of different elements like the exposed bricks against the copper walls, the long canteen style wooden tables and the roughly polished cement floor. These elements come together helping to create a modern and vibrant restaurant. Dr G and I went to Belgo to try the 2010 Lobsterfest menu which is available throughout the month of June. All the dishes that we ordered, apart from the desserts, were lobster based. For starter, Dr G had a Red Thai lobster @ £8.95 (half a Canadian 1lb lobster baked with a lightly spiced and nutty red Thai curry sauce). I am not one to mess around with lobster (I prefer mine simply grilled with garlic butter), but I was very impressed by the combination of flavours in this dish - the light Thai curry sauce gave some welcome chilli notes that offset the succulent, perfectly cooked lobster meat . The half lobster had been beautifully dressed with the intact meat from its claw sitting under the sauce at the top end of the lobster. I ordered a Lobster Thermidor @ £8.95 (half a Canadian 1lb lobster grilled with a light cheese, mustard and Orval beer)  this was again delicious with the creamy, mustard sauce accompanying the sweet meat perfectly. To accompany our starters we shared a bottle of Chimay Tripel £4.95 and another of Steenbrugge Blonde £4.35. These were excellent recommendations by our waitress, as both had a sweet spiciness, and long yeasty finish which stood up well to the Thai red curry. We also tried the Lobster Bisque @ £4.95  this is one of the cleverest dishes on any menu as little if any lobster meat is actually used for its preparation. I make this whenever we eat lobsters at home. The lobster shells are fried in butter and garlic together with a mixture of onion, celery and carrots. The mixture is then transferred to a saucepan while the frying pan is deglazed with white wine. Lobster stock is then added to the saucepan with some herbs, tomato puree, paprika and cream before sieving the soup. Belgo's version was excellent, with a strong lobster flavour, and a richness coming through from the brandy, tomatoes and cream. I could also taste a dash of heat from the paprika which added another layer of complexity to the soup. The bread was deliciously flavoured with caraway seeds. For the main course, Dr G had a Grilled whole lobster with frites @ £17.95. The lobster had been halved and topped with garlic and Pernod butter. The aniseed flavour of the Pernod butter worked well with the sweetness of the lobster meat and garlic; the lobster was sizeable and very good value at £17.95. I opted for Whole surf and turf @ £24.95  a whole grilled lobster with garlic and Pernod butter served with a 60z sirloin steak and frites. The flavours were distinct and simple but combined very well together. The double-fried chips were the perfect accompaniment to both dishes  they were very hot and deliciously crispy. To match our main courses, we had a bottle of blond ale Tripel Karmeliet £4.95 and an amber beer called Pauwel Kwak £4.95. These were again recommended by our waitress to accompany the more robust main dishes and I felt they matched our choices well. Dark orange in colour, they both had a good balance of hops and malt, and a sweet, fruity nose. The dessert menu had quite a few choices varying from £4.75 to £5.25. I ordered a Hazelnut ice cream with Chantilly and toffee apple sauce @ £4.75 which had an intense nutty flavour but

I8RlY7gN6vIzP0tZEAJbOg.text: I hope you have a better experience than me. The food was really lovely however our table of 3 had very poor service. We felt we had to remove the service charge of £18, but left £5 we got sworn at by the waiter, omg never before!

PhQQLJbuqr4LLKpXdod8pA.text: Absolutely love this place... found this place before i went on a trip to London.. Yelp once again never disappoint me!!! First of all.. for all the visitor this place is located at a very CUTE neighborhood. it's a little bit hidden, the sign isn't too noticeable but just follow the address # you will be fine.. The place is spacious, first thing I notice was they are specialize in mussels ( many different favors) they are all good. they have lunch special too.. They also specialize in fruit beer.. AMAZING.. loved it.. MUST TRY..MOST IMPORTANTLY.. LOVE THE DECOR....TOTALLY EUROPEAN STYLE.. can't find in U.S!!

kvUFW_PWoVu8k1-O2EQ5pw.text: While not my best meal in London this place is a reliable source for a good meal. From 12-5 they have a lunch special. We had the traditional mussels with frites and beer. They give you mayonnaise and ketchup for the fries; try them with the mayo. It's not bad actually. the seating in the basement is interesting, with long tables surrounded by copper tubing. We enjoyed checking out the Covent Garden neighborhood as well... it's a very busy area though.

-RM14DoA3xlye17KgfXMUQ.text: My dining experience at Belgo was one of the best I've had in London.  The atmosphere is lively with an industrial feel of exposed bricks and pipes and the hustling kitchen on display from the above entrance.  The place was packed but we got in with no reservation and no wait.  Service was attentive and food came quickly.  I got the mussels which were terrific.  Had a bite of my dad's lamb, which was superb- cooked perfectly with great flavor.They have tons of beers to choose from including the fruity beers that Belgium is famous for.  I had a banana beer, which was surprisingly really good.  My mom had a coconut flavored beer -also tasty.Great price for the atmosphere you get.

ggKFrKAPmX1oWczgBy0m4A.text: Visited this place on a whim on a Friday night with my CB. We were curious about the good reviews, we love Belgian beers/framboise and were in the area so we decided to check it out. Location! minutes away from Covent Garden tube station and the main hub so it is easy to locate. The entrance is somewhat deceiving as it looks like a club from the outside, the sign is subtle and the dining area is not visible and but you can smell the mouth watering food being prepared somewhere. As we approach the hostess, we were worried because there was a group in front of us waiting to be seated but likely this place is easy in accommodating 2 people so off we go. I heard it is important to make reservation for big group so be aware.Anyhow, we journeyed to the dinning area which is really interesting as it is underground. It totally reminded me of Hawksmoar restaurant down the street. The decor is pretty minimalistic but cool. The service was quick and food was good. I had the beef carbonade and CB had the traditional mussels and frittes. Both dishes were tasty although my carbonade was on the heavy side (at least for me). The frittes were nice and crispy while the Floris Apple beer was sweet and smooth. The prices of the food here is pretty reasonable but the beer as it is imported from Belgium is a big expensive. Good news to the Delirium Tremens beer drinker as you will find you such here. Verdict: Good Atmosphere, quick service and pretty good food.

Th6jJzQuQmv5R8nI3VDVjQ.text: This was not my first visit to Belgo's... but it might possibly be my last. It's a great place to go with friends and have a loud evening out, drinking fruit beers and eating mussels. On this occasion, I was sat next to such a group, which isn't half as pleasant. But ambience isn't a deal-breaker for me. I'm all about the food.Before we get to the food, I must say, one of the best things about Belgo's is there extensive "Beer Bible" - each one as delicious as the next, if I do go back anytime soon, it would be to check off some more of these beers. We got the classic mussels and the poppei - mussels baked with cheese and pancetta, and some sort of green pesto. I've had both of these before, and they were well executed, but this time, it saddens me to say, they were far below expectations. Now granted Sunday night before a bank holiday Monday is definitely not the quietest of times and they probably rushed through thousands of orders that night, so in part, I am to blame...kinda. But the mussels were overcooked, the chips were dry, the sauce with the poppei was just tame and awkward, I couldn't find any pancetta if my life depended on it. It's disappointing because I've had better at Belgo's.With hindsight, I think I'd like to give you another chance Belgo's, and I think I will, I'll just be mindful of when I visit...

Fjj2pFdASSSrJsPmdbI-Zg.text: Came here with colleagues and although the place is definitely a tourist trap (Even the host said so ;-)) the moulles fritte (Traditionelle very good, the Espanol supposedly with chorizo - but I am sure my Spanish friends would be outraged on a) this being called chorizo and b) the small number of pieces in it) were really good, the beer selection quite ok with not only the usual suspects. Why only 3 stars? Well, service was ok  - but not more.

WNZmpcJftpTQsFOukAI6Wg.text: I love a little Belgo. Chains are often a good thing. They typically provide a certain consistency and quality. That is an admirable feat in my opinion. They often also provide good value for money, because a lot of the overheads and running costs are cetralised... leaving a little more for lunch deals etc.I feel that Belgo is a good case for this.I prefer Belgo Noord. Nothing major, just small touches, like the natural light.

6vyBFbkQiy5ve4WCBOq_tg.text: We were in the Covent Garden area and saw that our tour book recommended Belgo as a fun stop to eat with great food.  We navigate the cobblestones streets to come to an industrial warehouse interior. The entrance was very unique and we didn't know what to expect as we did not see any tables or patrons, only a hostess standing on an illuminated walkway.  We were ushered down stairs into a large and boisterous dark communal beer hall, filled with happy diners and knew that this was a good decision! The atmosphere was casual and quite loud, but we could tell that everyone was having a good time.My husband was very excited with the beer selection. He liked that they also came out in the proper glasses, which is not of the norm in the states.  I was equally excited about the variety of mussels. I've never seen so many ways to prepare this dish! I had a hard time deciding on which dish to try.I decided on the moules bowl- the Snob (I did not stand up and shout "I'm a SNOB" as the menu dared me too) The broth was a very rich and creamy base, you could really taste the lobster. I thought it was a little too much for my palette but it did say 'rich' on the menu! it made it hard to finish my heaping bowl of mussels, I'm glad we ordered the mixed breads to sop up the brothy goodness, which probably contributed to me filling up so quickly. He had the roast Tomato, chorizo and Herb Rottiserie chicken and was quick happy with it. The frites were very delightful.We didn't get to sit in the restaurant side of the Belgo, but we did see the servers dressed as monks, running around the kitchen. All in all, I enjoyed our meal here. It was a good recommendation from our tour guide.

Znr8fupveqnMKWUj3gs8lg.text: Doh!  This place has so many specials. 7.95 for lunch with beer. On mondays get a whole kilo of mussels for 10 pouds.  For dinner, depending on what time you ordered your entreé,  pay 5-6.30 for your entree (M-F) between 5:00-6:30. And what do we do?  We come in on a super busy Saturday night when there's a ton of people and no specials!  Ugh!  Brilliant.  But i had a craving... hee hee heeI'd still pay the full 12.95 for just an order of mussels and fries.  As we were eating our mussels i noticed a few other dishes I wouldn't mind sampling.  The servers are quick on their feet and zoom by.  I need a stop sign.  Ooh maybe there's an App for that!

e7IYAVs2dRwL3LfzvZVntA.text: I would have loved to give Belgo Central a higher mark, but sadly it is completely eclipsed by the altogether less accessible, but infinitely more impressive Brouge in Richmond.Belgo has some good points, ie the comprehensive beer selection, and it's really cool to be able to look down on the kitchen staff as you walk in.Dining is communal, a bit like being in a Belgian Wagamama, with large tables shared between parties where necessary and a bustling vibe thanks to the open nature of the space. A big bonus is that the waiting staff all dress up in these horrible Belgian robes so you're guaranteed to not be the worst looking person in there :)Food wise, Belgo specialise in moules et frites, but as a vegetarian I had to stay away from the former. The choice of food for veggies is limited, with only 2 main course options on the standard menu. Very disappointing.There are a few more starter options, and we tried the white onion soup and the gruyere croquettes. Both were ok but not hugely inspiring.Julia had the seabass (see pics) which was apparently delicious. I had their summer tart, which was goats cheese, onion, rocket etc and it was pretty tasty (again, see pics).I'm sure that if I'd been a moules-eating man it would have been awesome, but I'm not so it wasn't.It was good, but not as good as Brouge!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Their Summer Special, there is goats cheese and mushroom under there somewhere.
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Seabass

gQR3AMGYHHGEZgnbr--qnA.text: Very busy place this time of year. We weren't able to get a seat in the main area downstairs, but we were lucky to be served near the bar. The hostess was very sweet and accommodating. Decent beer selection. I tried mussels and frites + fish and chips.HOWEVER, I obviously can't say with certainty but something gave me food poisoning that day... (and the only other thing I ate was a pastry that morning so I'm thinking it was from here). So be weary!

TRPBslzhoOYcmux5r9j9rg.text: The best meal I've had in London so far. I had the BBQ chicken wings for an appetizer. The meat was fall-off-the-bone tender. For my entree, I had the Sticky Chili & Kaffir Lime half rotisserie chicken with chips. The chicken was very flavorful and the chips were crispy and very good. For desert, I had a waffle with cherry sauce and chocolate ice cream. The desert size was fairly large. In all, a great meal.

SJkGx-hDTUyHqd5y18lYSA.text: Tastiness!I've been to Belgo Kingsway, and this Belgo Centraal blows Belgo Kingsway out of the water.  I ordered the moules frites (of course) Provençal as well as the chicken liver parfait as a starter.  The mussels were obviously fresh as can be.  Not a fishiness to a single morsel and not a single unopened sucker.  The fries are fantastic and crunchy!  The Provençal broth was lovely and light, but super flavorful.Chicken liver parfait (read: paté) was delicious as well, but somewhat irritatingly, they give you a rather large slab of it but only three little pieces of bread to accompany.  Actually, they seem to be a bit stingy on bread in general as most moules frites kinda places will give you some bread with which to sop up the broth, but not at Belgo.The service was spot on, and our waitress was wearing a delightful monk-ish getup.  Lots and lots of space, no wait on a Sunday evening just as shops were closing.Here's a little tip: if you go to the loos, there's a pedal underneath the communal sink that makes the water run.  I had about as much enjoyment as possible watching people trying to figure it out (there's only so long you can giggle at people in the toilets without coming off as creepy) before I tipped them off.

n_Y2ohxEn4C4PHxhrmcN_w.text: We had such a nice dinner at this restaurant. We had the pre-theater menu which was great. I started with calamari that was perfect with a delicious dipping sauce. The mussels in white wine were excellent. There is a huge selection of draft and bottles wine. Our waitress was attentive and very friendly. We had a great experience.

eKGQl4b7_foatlpqsVHeRg.text: Meh. I went with a friend and we each ordered a kilo pot of mussels with a side of chips. How were the chips? Frozen. Most likely, frozen. There was nothing special about them.The mussels at least tasted fresh, but A) there were a large number in my pot that didn't open and therefore wasted, and B) they have four different types of sauces the mussels are made in, but because the pot is tall and deep, you can't really get to the delicious sauce without either eating half the mussels or dumping half of them out. I wish they were served in a shorter, wider plate so you could actually taste the difference. My friend and I each got different "flavours" of mussels but the difference wasn't clear until about midway through. As for the atmosphere, I cannot figure out why half the staff is wearing monk-like costumes. Or why half the place is in a well-lit room and the other half (the room we were in) is dark and dungeon-like - complete with low ceilings. My not-very-tall friend found herself ducking to enter the room, which was a first for her. Not sure I'd go back, unless it was during a beat-the-clock special (from Monday-Friday, 5pm-6:30pm, you can get half a kilo pot of mussels and you're charged for whatever time you order them - so, order at 5:30, pay 5.30). I was surprised by how crowded the place was when we arrived, but when we left we were the only ones in the room. Food arrives very quickly; here seems to be a fast turnover.

jZZqVilI07YRpAaxhLBjlA.text: If you want to have excellent belgian dishes like Moules Frites or Carbonnade, as well as a variety of the best Belgian beers (they're all the best anyway :), without hopping on a Eurostar to Brussels' rue des Bouchers, then Belgo is the place to go !!!!

aR1c0dzM-czmlLXhQu5EGw.text: My friend counted 72 mussels in a 1kiloI usually visit this place, perhaps once a year,i.e. someone overseas comes over and we want to go to somewhere that's casual.let's talk positive. The mussels and beer never disappoint you. You get around 7 favours of mussels and yummy beer. Is a bit noisy but relaxing to say, last time I went, I was with a business delegation who were desperate not to talk about business, so down the beer and we start bitching about the boss. The financial controller was determined and start counting how many mussels are there in a pot. So it is 72 (not some statistics Belgo will give you or know)There was a the beer o'clock that runs to 6-ish, now it stops some ridiculous time, but it was nevertheless good valueOk the negative. I hate flies, I hate anything that flies. If I see even a beer fly I need to kill it before I stop thinking about it. Problem with Belgo is their wall is full of beer fly. The light is dimmed, so the person facing to the wall can't see, but if you are sitting next to the wall, the constant beer flies above my head and near me made me so ill that I need to get out of the place as soon as possible. So if they can get the beer flies out of the place I'll give them the 1 star that is lacking (don't worry, the beer flies don't fly into your food, they just irritates me)The other star goes to this cheap eats still cost me £20 per head.

1gMDyzVgJGp77RXmu1nBeg.text: Can't believe some of the (few) low ratings; this place is fantastic for moules, frites and a biere! All for about £20.00 per person (at dinner time).  And it's less than a one minute walk from the Covent Garden Tube Station.  Nice beer selection and friendly staff.  Great place for locals and tourists, alike.  This is my "go to" place when I'm in London and looking for a good meal at a fair price!

hT6Zs2-I0fbDEyOcYEVUAg.text: Great place.  Nice atmosphere loved the Thai mussels and beer selection.   Worth visiting when in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Cool beer from #Belgo
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Thai mussels and Satans Amber beer.   Awesomesauce

GMhwYHpvamgaxGqDOnnoHg.text: Whenever I am in London, I try to try out new places. This time, we went for Belgian. The place looks really small from the outside, but the actual place is huge, it coveres the entire downtown area. The menu is not big, but has a good selection. The portions are also huge and the service super quick, for us, paying took some time though. I opted for the fish, which was just more like basic fish'n chips. But friends opted for chicken, which were really good. The mussels are obviously the speciality here, and they looked delicious. The prices are also what you would expect in the area around 12-15 per portion. All in all a good option to go to when in the area and in the mood for some hearty food.

O7fJs6xVYSODueu7ruYFlw.text: I've been really wanted to try Belgo for ages (well months... two months), and I finally got the opportunity over the Jubilee weekend! My friend was in town, and we went to Covent Garden. After deciding we were ready to eat, I convinced him to check out the menu as I really wanted some mussels and chips. He's not the biggest fan of mussels, so I was concerned, but he found something on the menu so we went in.The decor is strange. My friend has been to Belgium, so I asked if they decorated places in the slightly strangely rustic/industrial way that Belgo Centraal was decorated. The answer was no, but I still didn't mind how it was set up. I went for the tradionelle and he had what basically equated to bangers and mash (hey, he's in the UK, why not bangers and mash, even if it's at a Belgian restaurant?). We ordered the bread and the croquettes.Well the croquettes came out, and I was expecting something potatoey like most croquettes are. These were small nuggets of fried cheese goodness. Seriously tasty. The mussels came out and looked amazing. The bangers and mash were also quite tasty looking. The mussels were hot and succulent. Seriously. Perfectly cooked and delicious. The garlic/wine sauce wasn't overpowering, but just enough to add a nice flavor to the mussels. I even convinced my friend to try them, and he may be a mussel convert. The chips were nothing special, but they weren't terrible. I'd definitely go back and try the varieties of mussels. So many choices, so many mussels! I felt a bit bloated after eating so many, but I just couldn't stop!

cH6ZquwdznRJUUxuK-hMBA.text: Much better experience if you book in advance. A great selection of beer and very cool venue. It is in a basement and you sit on benches. The classic and provancal moule et frites is good, but not very tasty. The Snob and Thai was very good, and had a lot of flavor.

OPkuyYhlhzU9cscXRJtOqw.text: There's no doubt that the food is good. The missiles are amazing though the fries are pretty ordinary, I've tasted better, and the great selections of beers is wonderful! But because mussels aren't really fulfilling, we left hungry and paid a lot considering the amount of food. The food is great but it doesn't worth the price :-/

Ngu1OrIMr87xugJy9wlBsQ.text: I think this restaurant is over-rated - for its food and service. I went there for their seafood and find it disappointing. The seafood I ordered werent fresh, and the service is appalling. We were present the bill after the waiter clean the table. Unpleasant experience.

dTQavVvQA563SgNXEDxmXw.text: Muscles was fresh, cheap and perfectly cooked. Highly recommended.

kIiZpripmz5TljX07LqQcA.text: Great green thai mussels and frites and an excellent choice of (expensive) beers. Eating earlier in the evening is cheaper as they have a 'beat the clock' offer. The waiters are somewhat bizarrely dressed as monks.

9-YZPihMrQJ_EUtp2jbeYw.text: This is an excellent join right in the middle of leicester square. It is always packed so you would be wise to book early. The owners have succeeded in creating a belgium beer hall equivalent by making it a very 'rough on the edges' restuarant. IF you go to Belgo's the standard dish is the mussels which are to die for. YOu are spoilt for choice on the beer front. Try some of the fruity beers and you will not be disappointed. Another good dishes are the steak and the lamb. Deserts here are also well done, the chocolate cake especially. THis is a fairly standardly priced place well worth the visit!!

I6ni1_9eAfIXN8_ielyfqw.text: Having been to Belgo's a few years ago and considered it a great place with keenly priced food, I was left feeling decidedly underwhelmed by my latest visit. Very average moules and a pushy attitude from the staff (who had clearly been instructed to put turnover in front of basic courtesy). I might accept this kind of behaviour from a service station or a fast food chain, but not a £30 per head establishment, I'm afraid.

B8-Fmi5KfS2pBIU4NXC_cA.text: Why? Oh why? Oh why?I want to know why people knock the Belgo chain - these places are such great fun. So what if you have to queue - don't be such a baby, have a beer and CHILL OUT (if you know how to). The busier the better, if you ask me. If you relaxed a bit instead of whining you might start to appreciate how generous the staff here can be - free schnapps? I love it.

0V5oHqI1CAaePV3YroZU6A.text: Mussels from BrusselsBelgo's is famous for it's mussels, so make sure you try them. And don't be boring and try a normal beer as they have a huge list of unusual ones, so see how far you can work your way through it. If the bar staff are in a good mood and you aren't rude, they often give you a free shot of Peach Schnapps. Yum.

THdXAqHPlbCHtGphYNqJuA.text: Belgo go goThis is a great place to go to with a bunch of mates. Just be sure to go early enough to snag a table or a nice corner and work your way through the beer list. It's massive. I didn't get any free schnapps though. Must be who you know...

2nk8QlWSaAXHcR8Glktg8A.text: Belgo: Studenty hang outI went to Belgo's when I was studying in London and it is perfect for a night out with a big group but it's not a place I would go back to time and again. The menu is very limited and the food is actually not that good but the atmosphere is kicking_ it's nice to be led down to the restaurant in a space lift and then be met by waiters dressed as trappist monks. Honestly, great for a cheap student night out not so good if you have a more sophisticated palate. Plus, as someone who lives in Brussels it does not do justice to fantastic Belgian cuisine!

uxclRXSF__TebOs1-8Do9Q.text: We went for lunch on the bank holiday, it was halfway crowded and we didn't have a problem getting immediately seated.   You walk over the kitchen and then head down stairs and walk right by the kitchen area to get to the main seating.  It had a very industrial/factory feel.The lunch express is fairly cheap, with the choice of a drink and a small selection of main courses.  We ordered the Traditionnelle mussels with frites and the grilled goat cheese salad.  We didn't have to wait long for our food, however they messed up our extremely simple order.  We got served (I think) the Thai style mussels and did not get any frites.  I was fine with that style, so I just asked them for the frites and they delivered them a couple minutes later.  They did not give us any dipping sauce however.  The frites were disappointing and very typical thick French fries.  Not the double fried Belgian style frites I expected.  The mussels were fresh and had good flavor, but they had to be the tiniest mussels I've ever seen.  Maybe this is typical for the lunch version of the dish?  The goat cheese salad was good and I recommend it, but keep in mind that it will not be very filling.All around, I got the feeling this place works better with a group of friends drinking and chowing down at night.  Since I didn't have that opportunity, I have to rate this place as a solid average for lunch.

GCq3JgIIDCJ9zYedUSDU_w.text: mussels, frites and steak-- you can't really go wrong! excellent beer menu and knowledgeable staff. large and somewhat cave-like dining room makes it noisy, but boisterous in a fun loving way. great for groups and parties. the only reason i didn't give it a five is i would love to see a better appetizer menu-- but with a big steaming pot of mussels, you don't really need the extra food!

GEOWWhLx-d1oLe4UBFQ8uA.text: This is a great restaurant to go with a large group of people.  They have a huge selection of beer ranging from safe (5% alcohol) to Ugh Oh (13%+).  Mussels are out of this world and come in a variety of sauces.  I have tried a number of items on the menu from steaks to seafood and nothing disappoints.  This is a hard place to leave without feeling great!!

nSN0NBCG2W_P2tXRWF95bA.text: I used to work at Belgo and there was a great team atmosphere but a lot of hard work because it is a very big and busy place, it can hold up to 450 diners at a time! The food is great, particularly the carbonnade flammande (beef stew) and the beers are lovely. If you go I would recommend asking the waiter to match a beer to suit your dish as this makes both taste better (e.g. a dark beer with the chocolate cheesecake). Sometimes the service can be a little slow, but hopefully you will always find it friendly!

oWzN2W8z_gnf9iqFNjTmRw.text: An invitation to join a crowd to eat at Belgo Centraal is not an invitation I am likely to turn down. I love Belgian food, drink and culture and even went there for a holiday this summer, fitting in Rock Werchter festival and a trip to Stella Artios brewery in Levuen during my trip. So when I find out that this invitation was a chance to sample the limited edition Oktoberfest menu where each course is served with a beer to compliment and we would have Sam (a beeroligist) at the table explaining the local nuisances and specialist styles and brewing techniques of Belgian beer I made sure I was there early, with bells on! I don't think the bierloigst is there for everyone to talk about beer and the brewing process, but lets see what I can pass on in relation to the menu and the biers available here at Belgo. Before eating, I went for my favourite style of beer, wich is unique to Belgium, a cherry lambic called Kriek. It was yummy and Belgo, who also run Bierodrome, have a huge selcetion of local Begian beers on drafts to choose from. So let me review my eating expereince of the Oktoberfeast available this month af Belgo. My starter - Parfait de volaille (Chicken liver)with a raspberry beer chutney and salad leaves. I would not usually choose liver, pate or such products but given the beer chutney I thought I would take a risk on the basis that, I, had never found De Konnick to be suitable to my tastes when drinking it before. However, this was the moment. It was perfect, a beautiful combination of flavours and despite my usual aversion to both liver and De Konnick, which Sam told us was so named to mean 'The King's Beer', I felt like a King with another combination of dislikes I love together. It instantly joined Jamieson whiskey and ginger ale in this unique club of mine. The other diners were satisfied with a wonderful beer I have tried before called Vedett Extra blond which hit the spot with Aparagus a brugsthat is around eight asparagas shoots in Brugs beer and chieve sauce to you an me. I wanted it really, but eating outside of the comfort zone is needed from time to time. The Main - Panse De Porc, Pork belly cooked in Brugs witbier served with spinach & butternut squash and a Rodenbach Grande-Cru cream sauce Well, a trip to Belgo means Mussells, chips, mayo and Kriek for me. So, time to turn down the moule and try something new. I knew anyone asking for the Moules Blanche on this menu would be happy, although cooking them with bacon, white beer and serving with Affigem Blonde was a new twist on me. There was another dish poking its beady eye out at me and this was called Flamande. I have not had one of these in the UK, but one I had in Lille was possibly one of the best winter dishes I have ever had in my life, even though it was May at that time. Sorry mumit beats the Cottage Pie and the stews you used to do. Sam tells us that the beer this is paired with is rather cider like and I can see that being a winner. In fact, I would go back and have that main course, because my choice was exactly what I wanted and satisifed me perfectly. The Pork belly was perfectly combined with the sauce, the butternut squash and spinach and as for the beerit was the best foriegn dark beer I have had in a while. So full of flavour and a complex texture it was ideal alone, but better with the dish. I am a fan of the Rodenbach Grand-Cru now. Dessert - Leffe Beer Ice Cream served with syrup de liege and pralines Oh, surprise, surprise, beer with everythingI bravly chose the Leffe ice cream hoping it wasn't dark Leffe, but found it was the blonde and it was much better than I could have imagined. The crunchy syrup de liege was nice to suck upon in the ice cold mouth and it rounded a wonderful evening of cooking with beer that Micheal Jackson would have been proud of. In fact I have a couple of Leffe drinking buddies who would enjoy this dish alone. It was however the craft of the Poire Pochee, a pear poached in cherry beer served with a peach beer sorbet which caught my eye for a later date. All of this washed down with another favourite of theduckFruli! They couldn't go wrong with me could they???? And for your eyesthe line up for Oktoberfeast in full OKTOBERFEAST Choose from the following menu and sample 3 specially selected Belgian beers for only £27.50 per person* (£19.95 for the menu without beer). *minimum of 2 people, maximum 10 per table Starters Asperges a la Brugswith a Brugs white beer & chive sauce Beer pairing  Vedett Extra Blond Parfait de volailleWith a raspberry beer chutney Beer pairing - DeKoninck Croquettes de FromageBelgian cheese croquettes made with Orval trappist beer Beer pairing - Orval Main Courses Panse De PorcPork belly cooked in Brugs witbier served with spinach & butternut squash and a Rodenbach Grande-Cru cream sauce Beer pairing - Rodenbach Grand-Cru Carbonnade FlamandeBraised beef cooked in Faro beer, nutmeg and brown sugar Beer pairing - Mort Subite Gueuze Bouchee aux Champignons SauvageA

lCgg3iw-WP65kCbWMBAbPg.text: i know its not a fresh story. still, its worth a couple of visits. the choice of beers is excellent, and the food is competently turned out by a hard working kitchen. even if you hate the robed monk schtick, ignore it and grab some decent grub and tasty beers after a day of shopping in Covent Garden and seven dials

Fy-NaRgIDik2OJPmy5ykVg.text: great deals to be had on mussels and beer!staff wear a weid mionks costume though

ewd903HhJlAjW1Y_-xueJg.text: This is like eating in a canteen, the food was a real disappointment as was the cherry beer. I'd heard really good things and have to admit I was expecting more.

HrMXT3Er0ecGiI9PFwGUDg.text: Fantastic, super busy restaurant. Does my favourite type of food, all washed down with a massive selection of belgian beers (I am slowly working my way through the list!)

fLD3DYZNrHmhc9wylvBbFQ.text: Belgo Centraal is totally unique in its design, especially its industrial lift, which transports guests over one of the busiest kitchens in London, where dishes from a menu of high quality are produced. Situated in the hub of Covent Garden, Belgo Centraal has been a hit since it opened in 1998 and a destination for tourists and Londoners alike ever since. Well known for its high quality Belgian food and drink, accompanied by unbeatable service and a stimulating environment, it has won a Best London Restaurant Award and was also runner up in the Best Family Restaurant Award 2000.

k1YRKZSTWGrATeL8T7JKoQ.text: A very nice place that offers decent food at nice prices. Mussels along with some Belgian beer, what could be better to wind down with? Plus, if you have the time to go during Mon-Fri 5pm-6:30pm, you can bag yourself a bargain with their beat the clock offer, more the reason to visit this place!

r_pUymngxB6u5JS1M9__ig.text: Between 5.00 and 6.30pm Monday through Friday, the earlier you get here, the less you'll pay, because for specific dishes - such as a pot of mussels accompanied by a bowl of fries with creamy mayonnaise or pork and leek sausages with mashed potatoes -  you're charged according to the time you ordered them, so  prices for these items range from £5 to £6.30. If you're a beer aficionado, you'll think you wandered into paradise. The food is very good, and the communal-style dining makes this a great place for groups or an ideal spot to make new friends. It's loud but a lot of fun.

_MPYhLFPG2lShM6zYQlmKA.text: I came here for a quick meal before going to the theatre. Brilliant little place with loads of atmosphere. I love how busy it is. A fantastic selection of beers on offer. I was quite partial to the 'slag' and the 'bush' beers. I went for the Beat the clock offer. I could not have been happier. I was recently in Brussels and was disappointed with the mussels I had. Not here. I'm a bit of a chef myself so I can honestly say I couldn't have done better myself. Give it a go!

j4C2q4Z0dtUjFldoiCFH7g.text: I love the chicken here- really really nice!! Service is good, prices cheap for what you get. Especially if you catch the 'beat the clock' promotion where you pay the time that you arrive. The strange thing about this central one is that you eat underground. There is also a 'holding pen' as I call it, upstairs, and when it is busy you can easily spend over an hour here (there is a large selection on beers to keep you busy while you wait). The trouble with this is that when you drink when you are hungry, when you eventually do get a table you are more interested in the wine list than the menu!!

WMz8FLi9WaOYyNOdzWyYmA.text: Top place for mussels and the odd chocolate Beer. If there is a long queue they'll shepherd you into a pen with a bar to while away the time, before dropping down into the abyss of the communal eating quarters. I once managed to convince a friend that all the waiters were actually ordained monks, this went on for most of the evening. Great banter from the waiters who will answer back at you for the slightest so be prepared for a good laugh.

SGM9yYzquyl6PphG_VU3hQ.text: I've been going to Belgo for years, and yet the resounding memories I have from it are always maintained: a mesmerising heat as you descend the stairs into the main dining area (this used to be done by lift, it hasn't in the past few years, unfortunately), a loud kerfuffle outside the kitchen, and a brilliant meal. After discovering the joys of mussels aged 9 (I previously cowered away from them into some chicken dish or other) I always order the same dish: a kilo pot of mussels in a white wine and garlic sauce with a side order of fries. The food takes just a bit too long too arrive, but when eating seafood I am always willing to allow for it to be cooked to perfection. The mussels are tasty, big and orange, but there are always a few unopened mussels left over, which, in desperation, I try to prise open. The chips are brilliant when ordered Belgian style - the staff will gladly bring pots of mayonnaise for your enjoyment. I become something of a glutton at this restaurant, scooping up the mussel sauce with empty shells to sip at it, despite it humming with garlic. For a quick meal, this is great, although the industrial ambience, which was once very progressive (unisex toilets?!) and exciting, is now a bit brutal. There is no sound but the clattering and the crashing of the kitchen, loud guffawing from nearby tables of fat men trying out obscure beers, and the heat becomes somewhat menacing.

3T6A-pxkJ2WkAjVzjHe4CA.text: This is cruel I'm salavating just thinking of this wonderful eating place buried beneath covent garden. You enter what looks like an industrial space and go down in a metal cage lift. The express lunch is brilliant, there is something truly joyful about moules,frites and beer. The quality is always fantastic and I have yet to enjoy a meal there. Children eat free with an adult if you choose from the main menu. My two seemed to really enjoy the surroundings and their food, can't praise this place enough.

G4RxXDeeV9dVPL5xEt3PxA.text: Belgo's is amazing. The food is delicious, and even if you don't get moules frites, you will not be disappointed. In fact, the rotisserie chicken is so good, I know people who go there specifically for it.There are two sections of the restaurant. If you make a reservation, you are seated in the quieter (still somewhat noisy) section with individual tables. If you don't make a reservation, you are seated in something resembling a beer garden. You sit on picnic-style benches, and the atmosphere is fun and jolly.Their deserts are also very good.

wf96efAmnq67fc50PYk7nw.text: I lived in Belgium for a while so even though this is a chain I find it hard to turn down an invitation to eat mussels from Brussels! A big pot of mussels washed down with some Belgian beer is just about as good as it gets. Prices are cheap and service is friendly although I feel sorry for the waiters who have to wear those monk type costumes - how embarassment!

GCJpDrb7dqHNpun2fJhzHg.text: my time there was very noisy, too warm and not so convivial food is good but not as the value paid. decor is unusual and nice, especially the entrance. maybe next time in another Belgo I should try the beer!

WnMe568LzluHK27kJGUfvA.text: Very nice place for mussels. There is also an offer called stop the clock between 5.30 and 6.30. basically, there is a limited menu available between this time and the price depends on what time you are seated. For example, if you arrive at 5.45pm, you will pay £5.45 per person Quite clever?

snwa0iLtIKbjlAiPfnsVJw.text: Went for a quick lunch before the theatre, cannot reconmend the Express lunch menu enough £7.50 for muscles, frites and a beer! Service was quick, friendly and food fantastic! Best VFM i have found in london. Can't wait to go back and sample the full beer menu!

CjRc7pX2-uctntihPYc1jQ.text: Once a major novelty, this still has an appeal for anyone looking for something slightly different. Founded on the principal of moules, frites & beers, the Belgian themed restaurant is noisy, sociable & fun. You can choose for a variety of sauces for your mussels, plus there are over 100 trappist beers to choose from. Seating is at bench tables and the main restaurant is a converted cellar, fashionably made over with a semi-industrial look. The waiters are dressed as monks! Access is via a zinc lined elevator, and in some respects you have the feeling you're entering an experience. Which you are! Oh and by the way if you don't like mussels there's seafood, vegetarian or meat dishes such as rotisserie chicken and Belgian sausages

hrRjrjP8__2h6rd9-dU60A.text: Normally, the food is a bit too pricey for me, but I went during one of the special offer times, meaning I got a meal and a drink from a selection at a reduced price. I was impressed with the food, and also that most of the staff were actually Belgian. They have a very interesting menu with something to please everyone, but I was even more enamoured with the beer menu; although most of my friends disliked it, I loved the banana beer. You can also get a loyalty card which is stamped every time you visit, and in the end , this qualifies you for some manner of free loveliness. Beware that they do add 10% service fee, which I feel is rather cheeky; I believe people should be at liberty to pay it or not pay it rather than have it just added on.

2QTgtmLHGBYkoiWiZZdaVA.text: The big one, with more Belgian beers than you can shake a wild boar sausage at. Moules frites and a beer is the best thing on the menu, and don't forget the mayo on the chips. Get there early evening and pay less, although the prices are great value all day. How do they provice the right glass for each beer? There are hundreds of them. You could think you were in Brussels, save for the pre-show chat from excited coach parties. A fine place.

KfmUXuUUCeNUkZ3c9SPTyA.text: The service was very attentive and constant, but when we asked for recommendations she literally said "try the mussels" and walked away.  The food was delicious, the alcohol selection was extensive, and it was a fun/unique place to be.  Great for groups.

lC0O95seug54k4KhNke6-A.text: I think this isnot a particularly good place for dinner. Althought the variety of beer is immense but this is about the only gimmick of this place. It is not really belgium food although they claimed that it is Belgium food restaurant. Even though the food taste alright, it is over-priced. Definitely not worth th trip to Belgo and I would rather spend the money somewhere else. The last time I went, we spent about £40 per person including drinks and the food was not great at all. It was also too crowded and the service was not good as the were short of staffs.

Tg0DuOZoDtDWEPOG5-YYTw.text: If you like beer, you'll like this place. Fantastic selection of Belgium beer both on draft and bottled. Can be costly though, although after your 5th pint money will probably be no object. All the beers are poured and served correctly so you get to experience it to the full. They now take deposits for Kwak as people were stealing the glasses - so that's a shame. They also do a large selection of flavoured vodka if beer isn't your thing.

47JiGkTBpT26i68hZOc5Qg.text: My first experience at a Belgo restaurant turned out to be a long wait as the queue was long, thank god they had a beer counter to serve those magnificent Belgium beers to quench my thirst due to the wait! However, once inside the place was fairly decent and food was above expectations, mussels were fresh and tastely, had the roast duck which was cooked just right thought the servings were rather small. Word of advice would be to make a phone booking or face the long wait!

iH0-3koOGcDaBDg7h7nxng.text: This is a fantastic venue and very characteristic, food was great. Like other people have mentioned, YES !! It gets VERY busy but def worth a visit

sLMvgYuTJuwXs_hoSx-fZg.text: They are currently doing a special promotion 'before 6' where you can dine for £6 provided that you order and finish the meal by 6pm. Went there a few weeks ago with some friends and find the food are reasonably good. Wouldnt say sensational but definitely recommended.

-zb0D0mt4VVa3O76k6eHtA.text: Great last minute find. Outstanding beer selection, both in bottles and on draught. The fish and chips were selected by two members of our group - older and younger - and both raved about them. One member got the chicken with a lemon wine sauce. Excellent. In addition, the downstairs location had a nice ambiance to it and the service was excellent.

19FgiBDhblPVGt8QupSkTw.text: One of my most frequent restaurants in London, thanks to my sister! My first Belgium food experience was also at this restaurant and my first impression was a great one, I remembered stuffing myself with some good steak. The place is often crowded and sometimes have to wait for a while for our table. Service was great, once it was our turn, they showed us to our table and paid attention to us (positively), making us feel comfortable and often ask us whether were were satisfied and anything else they could get us. Thumbs up for this service! The interior of the restaurant makes it feel like being in an underground or something but I thought its pretty present, only thing is it can get very noisy when its full. Lots of diners chatting at almost the same time is not very pleasant for our ears. However, the food made up for it!

VRANC22NL2RgnnevqSW7bg.text: Loved the mussel pots! I ordered the Thai moules pot (£12.95) and a salmon starter(£6.50). The mussel pots come with a side of salad, fries, or potato salad. Because I was greedy and ordered a starter as well, it was difficult for me to finish my meal. The mussels were so good (and addicting) that even though I was completely full, I wanted more!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom

mQSa43Ey6Pkdmxq4xpIuCw.text: Beer Battered Fish and Chips were great. Build-your-own desert was even better! Also, the atmosphere is very cool - downstairs hidden away with long bar tables that fill up the room

QyNAYhhjDQVtQf9oXNXyng.text: For a city that has no conception of speedy service.Wow. Great food, fast service and got me out the door prior to theatre tickets across the street.I highly recommend.

oBzbW3NvQ3eYNt3GZ4-S8g.text: I heard there's an excellent Belgian restaurant in London and being a Moules Marinière lover, I had to go to Belgo. I also wanted my husband to try good Belgian beer after last night's disappointing London Pride. We got there around 4pm to avoid dinner crowd. The servers were friendly and ambience was very vibrant. We started with Lobster Bisque which was flavorful. We got Moules Marinière (of course) and it was very good. We finished our dinner with Salted Caramel Ice cream. Life is good!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Inside
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Exterior

i3H-OTuklwKrKjCuSpjrVw.text: Came here on a Friday night with toe friends and had a great time. They called me in the morning to confirm my booking, which was a nice touch.It's all underground in a sort of warehouse-stylie set-up. The staff were really friendly and made lots of good recommendations for beer, which was great as I'm more of a wine girl, but you can't go to a place that serves over 100 different types of beer and get a glass of claret. I had the mussels in a tomato sauce, which was delicious. My companions both cleared their respective plates, so I'm guessing their food was sufficiently tasty. This review is slacking in detail because, in all honesty, we all got absolutely smashed and I don't remember a whole lot. There are photos on my phone of me crouching down in an abandoned suitcase in the street, so you know it was a good night. However, I do remember thinking that this place was the dog's cojones.

GYtxwCZ9oVkYcsay-0SNPQ.text: It has to be said that a chain that makes its living off belgian beer and frites should, at its core, be serving up some very tasty beer and frites.  Belgo is halfway there with a nice selection of beer on tap, but the frites here sadly leave a lot to be desired.  These supposed frites are glorified steak fries sadly, and not very good ones. Soggy, not crisp and not terribly tasty.  Having remembered this place after having been impressed by Belgo in my late 20s, I can say that either my tastes have improved or things are rotten in the state of Denmark, and Belgium too, if judging by the frites.I can see what I did like about the place though --a festive cavernous dungeon-like beer garden setting, almost like a nightclub, loud music, fun beer hall vibe, decent mussels options, etc.  However, not such very desirable frites, sadly.  BTW, we had a terrible service experience, which is, no doubt, coloring my opinion.  (Although the frites were still a failure, regardless.) We were seated by a nice hostess, then told brusquely three minutes later by a bullying floor manager, that we should have known better than to seat ourselves in a four-top as a family of three when they have many other guests waiting for a table for four.  Huh?  When got our footing, we pointed out that a Belgo hostess sat us here and we were just following orders.  Then did the floor manager apologize or try charm us for her error?  Nah, as you might expect she simply ignored the comment altogether and continued to insist we move to a shared tight seating situation with another party, on a fairly small table.  While I don't mind communal seating, hitting elbows and plates and possibly jaws with the neighbors isn't my favorite way to eat --the table turned out to be unusually close quarters for a family and another couple on a date.  All the while, the floor manager maintained the same annoyed fashion, that we were in the wrong, throughout. Meanwhile, the table we were booted from remained empty for almost our entire meal  --over an hour.  Later, we did have the original hostess come back and offer a round of snapps and an eye roll about her colleague's attitude, but at that point, we were pretty deflated.

SZ79fytPRx8c00hR8DroWA.text: Missed the happy hour, but had a good time nonetheless.  The beer selection is extensive, but only a few are on tap (mostly bottles).  The mussels are average (a little fishy and a little tough).  The lobster and crab burger had a little too much binding / filler for my taste (had a mealy texture in your mouth).  Loved the belgian waffle with sour cherries for dessert.  Ate every last bite!  Seating is communal and half the waitstaff wear monk's robes which is a bit strange.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Belgian waffle for dessert -- got to excited, excuse the missing parts!
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. A kilo of the classic mussels
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. The lobster and crab burger

Dn5dUAPr4nkW--xneVz9tg.text: Very good store design, drinks and food. Tai flavour mussels are good but maybe could be more seasoned, but big portion! Pork belly and mash were amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Tai mussels

TKszY8uPvsAa7lKy2OB3OQ.text: I really enjoy the Belgo chain, great mussels and chips and Belgian beer - that ranges from the very pale to the almost black. Great for the special offers like Beat the Clock, Express Lunch includes a drink served until 5pm, and Monday Mussels Madness. The food is good and the place is great for groups. Service is friendly.

9oIBj4y_T_h-vanfWE_31A.text: I arrived at 5:35 for the Beat the Clock deal (which runs from 5 - 6:30), so I was able to order half a kilogram of mussels (about 35) and fries for £5.35. The white wine sauce the mussels were prepared with was absolutely delicious. I ended up putting the fries into the sauce and allowing them to soak about the sauce.I also ordered a pint of Belgo Pils which was an appropriate compliment to mussels. Belgo Centraal also has an extensive selection of Belgian beers. The menu recommends trying the Bruges Zot Brune (a dark ale) which I intend on trying next time; I was unsure if the dark ale was going to overpower the mussels, so I played it cautiously.The restaurant is underground and the restaurant is furnished to provide an ambiance that matches the location. Additionally, the waitstaff was attentive and because I ordered a common dish it was ready fairly quickly.

SY9Cykmvg79-_OqdCqC3SA.text: This was another recommenedation from a friend of mine which totally lived up to its billing. When I look back on the various types of cuisine I ate in London, it reinforces the facts that it is a city with a diverse food culture and that, if you do your homework, you can find inexpensive dining options.The first thing you notice about Belgo is the building itself. You enter the building and take an elevator down a level where it feels as if youve been transported to the cellar of a Belgian monastery. It's dark, somewhat cave-like, and many of the servers are dressed like monks. As far as the food goes, we went there specifically for the "Beat the Clock" special which I believe runs between 5pm-7pm. The price of your meal is based on when you arrive--the earlier the better. One of the Beat the Clock meal combinations was mussels and fries. They were excellent. To get food of that quality for that price was really quite a treat in such an otherwise expensive city. Im not a beer drinker, but they claim to have over 80 Beligian beers... So I asked for a recommendation and tried one. Im not sure what it was, but it was tasty and expensive (more than my meal, by far). If you visit, though, Id definite partake in some Belgian beer just for the sake of the experience, if nothing else.Pros: Excellent atmosphere, interior design, Beat the Clock special, great food, vast beer selection, location in the Covent Garden areaCons: Expensive when not taking advantage of the Beat the Clock special

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Belgo Centraal
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Belgo Centraal
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Belgo Centraal

dX4ZKYBtO7aKOSnHz4UUUw.text: I love this little "hidden" belgo resto around covent garden, not only the mussels are amazing but the atmosphere is great! the servers are always nice, plus, they give u good beer recommendations ! Thumbs up :)

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Passion fruit cheesecake!
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Traditionelle

6GBgdvk9CceAFxTDNVALrQ.text: Hmm, I'm confused.I visited Belgo Noord for the first time in January and it was great, yet I've visited Belgo Centraal a couple of times recently and it just doesn't quite live up to its northern counterpart!The service is not as friendly or efficient and both times I've been the food has been sub par and bordering on bland!The first time I had the traditional moules... how on earth do they come out tasteless? With the garlic and white wine sauce, they should be bursting with flavour. And what's with the frites? I only got about 3 and, as Steve B pointed out, they appeared to be of the frozen oven-chips variety.The second time I had the crab and lobster burger and it left a lot to be desired for me. It was tasteless mush. Again, how on earth do you make crab and lobster taste so... nothing! There really must be an art to it. I didn't even bother finishing it and believe me, that's not a usual occurrence.Step it up, Centraal! Noord is way ahead of you on the service and quality of food scales!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Crab and lobster burger

I6lUEreXbzJZV_zfMsEh3g.text: Very nice place indeed! Went on a Sunday night, having made a reservation beforehand, as we had tried to get a table on the Saturday but were asked to wait 45 minutes... We were three people, sharing a kilo pot of the classic mussels and the "Snob"-bowl between us. Along with some of the rye bread it made a good sized dinner for all. There is no way I could have finished a pot on my own.. The Snob bowl was amazing, perfectly seasoned and nicely presented. The Classic was a bit dull, in flavour and execution, compared to the Snob. The place felt hip, pretty loud for a Sunday night, but all in all very welcoming and pleasant. The serving personnel were attentive and helpful. We were in an out of there in about an hour and 15 minutes.

sBrFrLSj32Tc4SdqJalD2w.text: Belgo is one of those places I walked by 4 years ago shortly after moving to London and thought "hm. Interesting. The boy might like this" and then forgot about. I remembered it last Friday night after we'd been out for some drinks and it was raining and all of Soho was full up. "There's the mussels place in Seven Dials." I said. My husband looked at me like I'd just made the idea up. "It's in the basement of a building. Trust me." So we went. And it was so so so good.Did I realize it was going to be cafeteria style? Nope. Did I care? Nope. We were seated at a big table with another couple who arrived about the same time. Lobster bisque = amazing. Crab cakes = divine. Roast chicken = tasty. Moules traditionelle = yummmmy. AND they carry Lindemann's lambics (& other fruity booze) Those things are so hard to find. I'll be going back just for the fruity stuff, but am looking forward to trying the "snobby" mussels in bisque. Mmmmm.

VXIn7QRuvQma2LkqZNFk1Q.text: Had and amazing evening here recently. Ordered the Lobster bisque and it was divine, went on to the classic Moules kilo pot and again very very tasty. I'm not a big beer drinker so the original pull of the place was a bit lost on me but I did try one of their speciality beers (chocolate and coffee one) and it was pretty damn good.

pBsOfs4SnhvbqIVRJOYVfg.text: My wife found out about Belgo Centraal and suggested we went along after struggling to find somewhere to eat on a Friday night without a long wait. I went in knowing very little, but left with an urge to hurry back!When I heard the terms "Belgian mussels restaurant" I had imagined a small, quiet place where we would be served a handful of mussels for an extravagant amount of money. I was pretty much wrong on all accounts.First of all - Belgo is a massive place. Endless rows of bench seating, a back room (which had a big party going on; a birthday or Stag night I assumed), and the longest kitchen/counter I have ever seen. I like being able to see the kitchen, and you couldn't miss this one, with scores of chefs and servers managing pots and pots of steaming delicious mussels. Belgo takes up an underground floor which must be a good portion of the full length of Earlham Street, and had that "undergound" feel with exposed piping, brickwork, and low ceiling arches. I like this look.First choice I had of course was ordering a drink. I didn't expect such a range of Belgian beer options, so it took quite a while to decide. I opted for a less-familiar lager; though many house names are available from the extensive drinks menu. Then onto the food - again a superb choice and not all mussels-centric. Of course, it makes up a significant portion of the menu, but given the choice of moules pots, bowls, and platters, this is no bad thing. I opted for the "Traditionelle" kilo pot - standard white wine, garlic, and celery - and a kilo is a LOT of mussels for under £13! I struggled to finish them after a light crab cake starter. My wife went for one of non-moules options; there was a decent choice here too, and was impressed with her starter of lobster bisque; and the rotisserie chicken main was good if not amazing. Given how tasty that bisque was, I wished I had ordered my mussels in a creamier sauce, but that was my choice and I do not regret it. It was a tasty introduction to mussels done properly!The waiting staff were very quick and friendly; especially commendable given how busy the place was. Also, despite this being a very busy time, we were never rushed and were allowed to take in the scene and the delicious Belgian fare.I will definitely be returning in the not-too-distant future to sample some richer cuisine and rarer beverages!

-pgrVUPVp715RqfzzZIPNg.text: Belgos is a hit an miss place most of the time. The only redeeming factor is that they serve Strawberry Fruli. In my younger days (before Yelp) I only knew of this place and Porterhouse in Covent Garden serving this beer. Now I know better! De Hems does it, I think the Slug and Lettuce had it on Lisle Street too! Plus, now there is Rekorderlig which is basically the same thing you can buy from supermarkets/get from most bars/pubs! No more need to feel bound to Belgos just to get a drink!THE PROS- Strawberry Fruli on tap, other Fruli flavours on bottles- Mussels, mussels and more mussels. Seafood offers. Loyalty cards. Beat the clock offers (pay the time you order the food before 630 I think?)THE CONS- Sometimes food is waiting at the front of the kitchen so long it becomes cold when it arrives. I once ordered a steak which was COLD when I got it.- Some mussels (like the garlic butter one - which is basically replacing French snails l'escagot with mussels) are super small for the price you are paying, it's almost not worth it.- The place is always packed. Most of the time it is also packed with big groups of loud and rowdy people.- Our order literally took over 1 hour to arrive. We were a group of 18 or so people. Really? Most of us ordered mussels! You just put different sauce in! - However, the manager agreed with our complaint and took off the price of starters (but only a few people ordered starters)

1byCXAmQtEMlGsARhd09gA.text: Dark basement, loud music, communal seating, drunk people, meh service, good beer selection and mediocre food. Overall, an okay place to go out with friends but not a great place with your family or if you want to have a conversation.

coDBBxPVYqak136ZI5a0Aw.text: Different. Great for a fun, casual drink/meal. Perfect for groups.I did not 'beat the clock' but I recommend you do -- come sometime from 5-6:30 and your meal will be the price at which you came. Neat concept! I had one of their dark beers- the aroma of barley was so strong and it tasted as good as it smelt: full-bodied and smooth. I had their beef carbonnade - a little too sweet for me and the sauce a tad overdone, but overall pretty good. Next time I will have to try the mussels based on all the reviews below!

DYrLL3RIujOrhA84nNIytA.text: The long list of Belgian beers should be reason enough for becoming a regular, but in my experience, Belgo Centraal also serves the best fish and chips in London: great beer-batterered fish, excellent peas with mayo (not greasy rubbish like in most places) and crisp, tasty chips. A pleasure to return each time.

NAh5ItSB7PpOthpsg5-SbQ.text: Belgo. I love you. Beer, meat, and frites. What more could a girl want? Your extensive drink menu left me wanting to never leave. The only reason I ordered food was because I succumbed to peer pressure. But in the end I was happy that I did because it really complemented my beverage. Ah... so many drink choices...I was impressed by the toilets. Not only did I enjoy tinkling in a uniquely designed stall layout, I also liked meeting some really nice people at the unisex communal sink. Tip to all you non-handwashing men: We notice, we remember, and we tell our friends. That being said, nothing says, "sexy," like a man with clean hands :)

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. The communal sink was another great place to meet people.
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Clearly, this doesn't do it justice. But I was really quite impressed.
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. They were really quite nice. I HAD to take of photo.

dH8qrTiNEDdxl4I61PGpfA.text: It makes me sad that I felt quite disappointed after eating at Belgo Central because I truly wanted to like it. I thought the place was awesome when we went down to the 'dungeon', as someone has called the huge underground beer garden of Belgo. Service was nice, atmosphere was relaxed and funny, it's a place to have a great time, really. But my goat cheese salad was small, didn't have the roast tomatoes announced in the menu, the 'croutons' where 3 small pieces of chewy baguette... don't know, at £9.00 with apple juice plus service, I think it's better to go to Food for Thought nearby.
