702FPMTZytr5euy7kZVlog.text: I came back here again. I like the fruit beer. The mango one is really good. They also have passion fruit and coconut flavor. It tastes like fruit juice with a bit beer taste. It's mild and sweet and good for the ladies. The mussels I had this time seem to taste better than the ones last time. I tried the green Thai, traditional, and garlic and herbs. I like the traditional the most, garlic and herbs the second and green Thai the least. I guess probably I like the seafood flavor better than the sauce. I tried their waffles too but nothing special .

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom

Zp6uZiRf1BnyhTd0gallGg.text: Was convinced to return here by a friend. She insisted they had the best lobster ever.They don't. And I've previously written about the chicken.Instead you pay £28 for a smaller lobster than you can get at Big Easy for £20.But wait! They have a special lobster festival menu, where you can order a SMALLER one for £35 that's a whole lobster that somehow has no claws! And is closer to the size of a crawfish.And when you query it and you have the regular lobster and the special side by side on the same table they will somehow find a way to insist that it is indeed a whole lobster. That's right. This more expensive and smaller lobster with no claws is a whole lobster according to Belgo.And when they take it away and bring you a regular lobster instead, they don't cook you another one. Instead they grab the first one they see so some other customer is also delayed. And you get a replacement lobster that has weird black stuff in it. Because that other customer had asked specifically for balsamic vinegar to be poured into half the lobster. So it looks like you're about to have that black stuff on the alien planet in Prometheus.And then you get the bill and it still has the optional service charge automatically added.So it's gone from 2 stars to 1 star. Sorry Belgo but you suck.And the moral of the story is stand your ground and don't listen to the girl. Life is too short to queue up for bad food in a hot, stuffy basement on a summer evening. Nothing will convince me to return here.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Is this black stuff going to cause an alien with acid blood to grow inside me?

FIo59arRB1t-ImOIwYCKAQ.text: My sister and I happened to be in London one weekend and I had asked friends in advance for something near the Lyric Theatre to eat at that was decent. Belgo was suggested so we decided to give it a go!So it appears the upstairs area was more of a bar and downstairs was where all the eating happened. We were seated in a narrow passing as it was just the two of us, this made for a rather "cosy" environment, not the best place to sit, to be honest. It was also dimmer where we sat, so I can't help but feel we got the worst seats in the place.We decided to get some drinks since it was a wet evening. I ordered the Boon Kriek Lambic Cherry since cherry is my favourite fruit flavour (next to pear). This is a gorgeous fruit beer and quite high on my favourite alcoholic drinks. It's not as sweet as ciders but still, has that fruity taste. My sister ordered the Floris Framboise which I also recommend.Given the fact that Belgo's two main selling points were their mussels and rotisserie chicken, we decided to order one of each to see if they lived up to the hype. Our small table struggled to store everything we ordered, as you can see.The Thai and Kimchi moules were awfully tempting, but alas my sister does not eat spicy food so we had to compromise. We ordered the herb and garlic moules in the end, this has the added benefit of actually being able to taste the mussels. These were quite nice and substantial, I'm not a mussels connoisseur, but these were a-ok and I'd happily come back here again if I had a mussels craving.Next up was the Belgo Beer BBQ chicken. The sauce on this was soooo good and the chicken was very tender and moist. It's a shame the chicken looks so sad on its own as the sides came in their own bowls. Overall, a thumbs up for me.For each main, you had a choice of sides to accompany them. You can choose between bread, chips or salad to accompany the mussels. For the chicken, it was chips or salad. I had thought that the bread would be perfect for mopping up the sauce that went with the mussels, but I decided to go for chips in the end as it sort of went with both chicken and mussels. I would recommend you go for bread if you are ordering mussels, though!The salad is very much needed as there was a distinct lack of veggies in the meal. Although the salad was very varied and dressed nicely I did feel that the salad was disproportionally small, compared to the chips.The speculoos cheesecake was a must, even though at this point both of us were rather full. We shared one and the Lotus biscuit pretty much fell after I took this photo, it probably wasn't necessary. The cake was delicious although on the small side for £5.50.Overall, he atmosphere and seating weren't brilliant. The staff were very pleasant and quick, though, so we weren't made to feel like third class passengers in service as least. I felt that they were ever so slightly overpriced, especially the cheesecake  The small salad was also disappointing, more salad, please! I would probably not visit Belgo again. The place was nice but nothing spectacular. As the chain only seems to be in London and Nottingham, I don't think I'd visit again as there are other places I've yet to eat at.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Speculoos cheesecake
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Belgo Beer BBQ chicken: Sweet, sticky & smoky
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Cooked frites

m-YG5Ry5cKAviDlX0-SPXA.text: Great Belgian beers, mussels were delicious and service was great. Cool vibe and atmosphere downstairs. Highly recommended.

HHw10okkmN62UJyBe7F-pQ.text: Sorry Belgo II'll give you 2 stars as at the end, the only thing really tasty I had was the beer. Dinner for 2 during the week: this place could be interesting if you are large group of friends but for a couple could be too noisy (the open kitchen add another layer of  noise on top of the one coming from the big tables around you)Menù is not so big which is good but what you'll get is an average meal from an average franchise. I had the chicken (make i simple choice) which was not particularly amazing, not tasty and also the inside was cooked ok-ish (some parts could have been cooked more). My friend had the mussels with chips which he said were ok but as I said before, nothing special ,the chips were better than the mussels.The only thing that was good were the fried calamari, tasty and properly crispy!Beer selection is huge and brilliant, they also have the Leffe on draught. I had the PAUWEL KWAK which was really good and served in glass with wooden stand and my friend had a Trappiste,Westmalle Tripel, also really good.Other than that, my friend Belgo, what I would suggest to you will be: be more authentic in terms of food, as your drinks are amazing already, and you'll be paid back with better reviews (at least mine!).

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Maybe not cooked as I was expected to get for a grilled chicken.

wdOHsx4F4GI3xnOWGPWO6w.text: Came here with my two kids at lunchtime. Great staff, food comes quickly. Next time we will leave room for chocolate fondue dessert.

zaZKmlNRNGvUJyLP4y2lag.text: Got the steak and cheese platter here, it was good food and really cool basement area.Friends got various beers, almost all of which, they enjoyed.Not a seafood or shellfish guy, so I'm not the perfect reviewer for their big menu items.Cool place to go on a date or with a group of friends though!

dU_ths75pdxEtcxCG6gs-g.text: Fun venue in a large, cavernous, subterranean setting. You head down either a warehouse-style elevator or metal-caged stairway into a maze of brick-lined arched tunnels branching off in different directions with long benches that make for great cavorting with large groups.The food is not bad, and even traditional Belgian items like mussels come in gigantic kettles that are worthy conversation starters in and of themselves. Also, the Belgian beer selection is amazingly extensive and covers different styles, including trappist, gueuze, and fruit beers.The adventure even extends to the unisex bathroom with the communal washing fountain. Potentially makes for quite an interesting location to practice those pick-up lines on folks.

ZIB5yte0V6chWCYTHZgBWA.text: I remember more than a dozen years ago when I came to London for work meetings always looking forward to an evening with dinner and a show.  My coworkers, who were far more senior than me let me tagged along and introduced me to Belgo.I finally came back today for lunch. It's a tiny door to get in, and then you descend into this gigantic basement full of tables, bars, and a massive open kitchen.  It's like a warehouse environment with the waitresses dressed in black and waiters dressed like European soccer players. Their specialties are mussels, fries, and Belgium style beer!I started with a pint of Strawberry Fruli beer - one of my favorites since it's sweet and goes down smoothly.  The foam reminded me of cream from Asian bubble teas!  I was also surprised to see banana, coconut, cherry, and black currant beers as well!For lunch I got the 1-kg bucket of mussels, served Traditional style, which is a light garlic white wine broth with parsley, onions and celery.  Mussels were fresh and tasty. Despite being smaller than ones I've had in the USA there were so many of them it took a while!  They offer bread also if you like to dip the broth.  Fries came with the order and were seasoned, and crispy.  This place is probably funner with a group, since you can mix and match from a dozen or so different preparations of mussels from your friends.  Plus you might get to try more of their wonderful beers!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. 1 kg bucket of Traditional mussels, with fries.
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Pint of Strawberry Fruli beer, one of my favorites
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. nice FAQ describing the very many beers they offer. Including lots of fruity ones.

hAfsBFV2hBkjnlllvuJQdA.text: So I finally got around to visiting Belgo Centraal.  Not being much of a beer drinker and not even a huge fan of mussels in meals in the past, I wasn't expecting much.When I entered, I was surprised by the industrial vibe going on.  I thought to myself, 'Where is the dining room'.  I walked over what appeared to be a bridge overlooking a kitchen.  'What's that down there?'We went downstairs after speaking to the host, where the restaurant opens up into an industrial-style canteen, with the open-plan kitchen as a centre point.  The place was loud and festive.  I looked over the drinks menu and was taken aback by the sheer number of beers on offer.  All the fruity beers piqued my non-beer-drinking interest, and I opted for Mongozo Banana Beer.  The Husbatron Prime ordered Chimay Bleu, seasoned Belgian beer drinker that he is.  Since we were at a restaurant known for its mussels, I decided to order a mussel pot traditionelle to do a litmus test of tastiness.  (Husbatron ordered the duck.)One word.  Delicious.The Mongozo Banana Beer was so exotic and exciting to the non-beer drinker in me that I wanted to try all the fruity beers on the menu and then some.  The mussels were above average, so much so that I'm now interested in returning for some of the more inspired varieties on the menu.  The frites that came with both meals were obviously frozen food-service chips (I had my suspicions and then I saw someone pour them from a bag into the fryer on my way to the toilet), but they were as enjoyable as any deep-fried potato would be, really.  Speaking of the toilets, I found them a bit confusing.  They were virtually communal but segregated toilets with a central (although more toward the men's toilets than the women's ones) carousel-looking sink.  Two bathroom attendants were present, with the usual array of cheap colognes and a completely obviously placed tip plate.  I really don't like toilet attendants.  I can wash my own hands and really prefer not to return to my dining companion smelling of cheap hooker.  And then I have to go and be all guilt-ridden for not tipping them for squirting some soap into my hands and handing me a towel since I was caught unawares having gone to the toilet without any money.Oh yeah, we also got dessert, which, refreshingly, didn't taste like simply an afterthought on the menu.  The bread and butter pudding was scrumptious.  I think it was better than the Husbatron's Belgian waffle, although he would probably say he enjoyed his just fine (dessert envy).I have to be honest when I say that most of the stars for Belgo Centraal are going toward the sheer volume and breadth of Belgian beer offerings on the menu.  Because of my visit here, I'm inspired to visit Belgo's more bar-like Bierodrome on Kingsway, which will probably result in me getting good and hammered, since I want to try, like, every beer on the drinks menu.

_HvHauej0uMzYlKSHXtjCA.text: Belgo Centraal is a fantastic option for theatre-goers in centraaaaaaaal Laandun, for four main reasons:1. It takes bookings, but even when the 'reservation area' is full, you can turn up and get a seat pretty quickly if you get there early enough as there is a lot of seating space.2. If you do get there early (which may well be the case if you are indeed planning on catching a show) then the Beat the Clock deal (pay the time [between 5 and 6.30] for your food) is fantastic. Warning: not all mussels are part of this deal, as they curiously seem to be in the Northern branch - something to do with north/south divisions, probably.3. The service is quick quick quick. Ok, so I eat my food too fast, but I had finished my meal less than half an hour after arriving!!4. It does what it says on the tin i.e. it's centraaaaaal. That means you can walk to Shaftsbury Ave or the Strand in less than ten minutes. Winner.Other than that, the food is really tasty (and some of the mussels are heeeooouuuge) as well as the massive list of beers for pre-show oiling.

MAyxCx-QJd_I0fGoWlKaaw.text: It's casual, quick and dependable for a decent quality meal. The menu boasts a highly impressive selection of mussels at quite a reasonable prices. And of course if you're a Belgian beer fan, you'll love this spot. Personally, I'm not much of a beer drinker, so it's a 3-star review from me, but if I was a beer fan I'm sure I would have added another star. Don't drink too much of that crazy high alcohol content Belgian beer though as you may never find your way out... the place is a maze.

fmvQoMNq5yIxWk99DYwCgA.text: Very classy and cozy restaurant in the center of London. Me and my friends are regular visitors there because we tried the Belgian beer and just fell in love with it  I prefer the lighter one but they all seem to be great. Also, the waiting staff is very polite and you can talk to them about anything  it is not awkward or tense  they act like normal people and don't annoy you with unnecessary presence by your table.

xYbtMrwYU4_oFC3LneOcVw.text: Went here twice in two weeks.  It's hard to find good food in London in my opinion.  This place was recommended to me by tons of people, so it had a rep to uphold.  It did so.The mussels - I've had the tomato based and the traditional one, both are great.  I've had the lamb, the duck, the chicken, and the sausage.  Lamb and duck were probably my favorites.  The wine sauce with the duck complimented it well.Of course, it has to be said that they have an extensive list of beers.  I tried several I've never had before and I don't remember any of the names.  They were pretty good and VERY alcoholic.  Watch yourself with those 9% beers!I've had every desert menu item (yes, literally) and my favorite is probably the apple mango crumble.I'd give it a 5 but I think the food and definitely the beers are a wee bit overpriced.Oh yeah, lastly, the bathroom, while interesting in design (you'll see) , is very annoying.  Sometimes there is a person there handing out paper towels and giving you soap, with a tip tray nearby.  I'm sorry, but this place isn't fancy enough to warrant that.

Dt4lp4BxTNTD7AZPITDRWw.text: My wife and I are in London on business and we decided to try to get to Belgo for their beat the clock special. Work ended up making me miss the time, so we settled for a normal seating around 7:30 after walking around the area. Not too long of a wait, we ordered the mussels and frites (I got the Mariniere, wife got the Traditionelle).  Beer selection, as noted, is huge, I won't go there but will instead speak on the mussels -Overcooked. At least my wife's were very overcooked. Mine were only slightly overcooked. Mariniere was tastier than the traditionelle which were quite bland, but both were mediocre to okay only.Had us both thinking about / craving our go-to spot back home- Flex Mussels. Decent place to get generally okay mussels and a huge beer selection. Perhaps the other food is better. I think the beat the clock special is probably very worth it. Liked the decor...

SS8FjYl_j0UVEDCOFOOW1w.text: Came to belgo centraal for beat the clock before our long outing with jude and hamlet.  Managed to arrive and order by 5:30pm, so our meal cost a whole £5.30- which was pretty cool.I had mussels and chips- the mussels were 1/4 massive, 1/2 ok and 1/4 stringy and the "soup" was pretty tasteless- basically water (not even salty water!) with a few bits of celery floating in it.  Z had the mushroomy chicken- which was massive, but had trouble eating it with her knife and fork because it was so dark that she didn't really see what she was doing.  Chips are ok, but tooootally undersalted (not sure if my taste buds were affected by my holiday, I might be feeling extra salty at the moment).  Both of us had kriek beer on tap- not very cherry-y, but we didn't feel like forking out a fiver each for a fruit beer.So far, so 3 star.  Unfortunately the evening was ruined by the staff desperately trying to usher us out of the restaurant despite there being a few empty tables around, and we were done and dusted by about 6:15.  Actually, I quite like to slowly enjoy my beer and pick at the remnents of my chips without you hovering to the point of us leaving just so that you will leave us alone.  Minus 1 star.With beat the clock it came to £10 each, which isn't that cheap.  I'd rather eat and be somewhere else, which would explain why I haven't been to this Belgo for over a year.

58PsJ04c-IA1VaoePhWxjw.text: Setting - Good setting though quite cramped as the table's are close together but the lighting is nice and bright.Service - Friendly service though nothing special.Food - Very, very good. I had a bacon and duck starter which was lovely, very nice light starter. I had beef carbonnade as a main and it was lovely if a little sweet when you bite into a plum. The chips were top notch and mixed well with the food. Drink - Had a chocolate beer which started off nice but didn't hold it's flavour all the way to the end. Wouldn't have it again. Overall - I would go here again and have already recommended  it to a number of people.

89E8CWcW7WY0RCV55xL9vA.text: This has quickly become one of my favorite go-to places in London. The beat-the-clock menu is, well, unbeatable. You pay according to the time you order, so get there between 5-6:30. Service is quick. The mussel and fries are great, especially when washed down with their delicious strawberry beer. Their wild mushroom puff is also worth mentioning. I would skip dessert - just spend your money on the beer and lots of it. Most importantly, how often do you get to have a waiter dressed up like a monk?

kSVOJnw6DaeI9x1sVfD-UQ.text: I'm not a massive beer or mussels fan but if you are this is just the ticket. The options outside of these are slim which means it can be a limiting experience. i think the quality of the food is ok and the service has never been amazing. i think there are many better places to eat in covent garden.

fbk4d-0fS56cj_6NQwP_nA.text: The food here sucks.I came here with an out-of-town friend, and I was hoping to show him a unique dining experience and that contrary to popular belief, food in London is progressive and delish. Alas, the Green Thai Mussels were small, mealy and in a mediocre sauce. The beer-battered haddock was disappointed-battered. The waitstaff was disorganized (starters come before the main course? no!).On the upside, there was a large selection of Belgian beers and the ambience was unique - slick entrance and tables in a mod cafeteria style.Perhaps this place was decent back in the day (given the number of positive review here) but the food quality is reminiscent of McDonalds, and the service is far worse than anything I've experienced at the golden arches.

v82Ln3-FvxuCARJ-CQK71w.text: Mussels, frites, belgian waffles w/belgian chocolate sauce, and belgian brews on tap- what more could one need?You can't go wrong with the mussels here but be forewarned that each mussel pot order is a kg (~2.2 lbs) not counting frites. I've tried the traditional and green thai- both very delicious.  For starters, the grilled goat cheese is devine and the salmon fishcakes are good, though a bit on the fried/breaded/carb-loaded side.If you have room for dessert (or just want a food-coma), definitely get the belgian waffle w/ice cream and chocolate sauce. They don't skimp.As for brews, you can't go wrong with a pint of Chimay, Hoegaarden, or Leffe. For sweet lovers, they have Strawberry Fruli. Also interesting to try (at least for me) was the honey beer and the chocolate beer.The main seating area is in the lower level and its canteen-style with its long tables & benches. The servers are dressed as monks. The beams have hooks so you can hang your coats. The lighting is dim, and the ambiance is lively and boisterous. For Friday nights and weekends, bookings should be done. For bigger groups, bookings a must. Now, it does take quite a time to have a full meal here, so don't come expecting a quick lunch. My going-away lunch here took us about 2.5 hrs and we had about 15 or so in our party.I wish there were Belgian places like this in the US.

Rw5y33Du4Hd62MK1eSc9Hw.text: Don't go to Belgo for the food... don't get me wrong the mussels were great, but it's really about the beer.  Check out the "beat the clock" times if you want to get a good deal on food, otherwise just order some food and eat it up so you don't get completely ripped from the Belgian beer.  The beer MENU is pretty awesome, just beware that many of the beers are ~10%.

wuFFQE33EZaLUerIuh_2Dg.text: Staff were really on the ball, we were never left waiting but at the same time no intrusion into conversation. We opted for the express lunch; rotisserie chicken and a half pint of cold cold beer. Both were lovely and complimented each other, it's good to see somewhere serving chicken on the bone, I like little danger with my meals and there's nothing more satisfying than rendering a carcass clean of meat amongst gentlemen. The atmosphere and layout is fantastic, with the entrance walkway overlooking the kitchens, flames and smoke dragging you down into the depths of the cellars. Staff don monk uniforms and it gives the impression that you're invading some cult in the middle of London. But fun and not a strange electrode machine in sight.

WcRD-MB7b7ytpmetxBYGhw.text: I went to Belgo and took advantage of the Beat the Clock menu.  If you arrive between 5 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. you are able to order from a list of entree's.  The price is the time you arrive.  In our case 6.30 sterling since we arrived at 6:30 p.m..  A pretty good deal but the food was not very good.  The fries were not very good and the Mushroom Chicken was fairly bland as were the mussels.  I would give the food two stars and will not be having it again.Belgo's saving grace is their excellent selection of Belgian Beers.   I was unadventurous and had the De Konick which was excellent.  If you go, just go for the beer and you will not be disappointed.

QYDw2graGHgtqEq2pfTfgA.text: Really busy on a Thursday night. Service was awful to begin with.  We were sitting for at least 15 minutes before we were handed menus (we had to ask for them).  The waitress who eventually gave us menus asked if we wanted them.  We all had mussels which didn't taste very fresh.  Sauce was watery and bland. Frites were average at best.Bread tin was tiny.  Good selection of beer though, although some were quite pricey.  Won't be returning.

Drg9QBsEQ-htF8jPyLqyvQ.text: So many beers and the waiter helped me pick a rare one that I wouldn't normally find elsewhere. All the food was delicious. We had a party of 9 with 5 young kids & the staff was accomodating.  We ate mussels, beef, frites,  and desserts.  I loved the atmosphere, the food, and the service.

7tFqtIFbQW9KC5XXl3MbJA.text: On the back leg of my fantastic honeymoon, we once again found ourselves in the midst of an 8 hour layover in wonderful, sunny London! That's right, 80 and sunny! So you wonder why we spent the better part of 2 hours in an underground Belgian restaurant? That's what I thought, until Mark started bringin' the beer!My bud Shoe left us an email that this is the spot we should hit up during our brief stay before heading back over State's side, so we ventured over to Covent Garden. After looking around like the idiot tourist we were, I finally spotted the red flag posted on the side of a discreet brick building.Why the hell would shoe send us here? I mean, cool interior, nice lunch crowd, but kind of looked like another chain from the US of A.Not so fast.We sat down at our communal table and Mark asked us what we fancied. We opted for what their known for (at least what Mark said they were), mussels and fritas. Mmmm, delish! The mussels were cooked perfect, that is, falling off the shell, and the fritas were long and crisped to perfection. But enough with the food... On to the main event!My first beer was the one I fell in love with at Holly Bush, Stella. Des opted for a Delirium, which is now one of her faves (not sure if its for the beer or for the mug with the purple elephants!) I then moved onto a Chimay Reserve after my 2nd Stella. I don't remember what Des went for next (hey, a couple of Stella's followed by a Chimay and nearly 5 years ago will do that to you!) But hey, maybe it was the 4-5 samples Mark insisted that we try during our stay! So this is why Shoe sent us here!As the room started swaying, I think it was Des that talked Mark into parting with a couple of his purple elephant Delirium mugs!Not to make the same mistake we did on the leg over, we left Belgo happy and 3 1/2 hours before our flight. We took the Underground back to Paddington, arriving about 2 hours pre-flight."I'm so happy we wont be rushed this time"An hour and twenty minutes later, the train arrived. 2 trains delayed, we hopped on board, now extremely nervous. 1/2 hour trip, and 10 minutes to storm Heathrow until we miss our flight.As the train approaches the terminal, we ready ourselves at the door, like sprinters in the blocks, and...BOOM!Doors open and we sprint to the security line. Des begs the person in the front that we now have 8 minutes to make the flight. He feels bad, and lets us pass.Next the escalator. Actually, I can't quite remember if this was before the security check or after. Hey, I was about 6-7 beers down and this WAS 5 years ago, so who cares!I fly up the escalator, with Des in tow, when I hear a shatter. I turn to look, and see her souvenir mugs all over the floor! They had fallen out of her backpack and were now spread all over the floor of Heathrow!She looks up...she looks down at the broken mess...5 minutes."RUN!!!!" I scream. And she does.We sprint down the terminal (again) and just catch the Gate checker closing the gate."Wait! Wait!""Oh, there you are! The Gallaghers, I presume?"Ahoy. On our way!Oh yeah, the plane had a technical difficulty and we sat on the tarmac for another 45 minutes!

lDtdcezhVXTeoH4pJJzcGg.text: It had been a long, long while since I ate here, and I took a date who was kind enough to pick up the bill. Had fortune not smiled on me so unexpectedly, Belgo would probably have lost another star in addition to:- - one docked for service; slow and a little unfriendly. This varied from server to server, as the one who admitted to an error in accompanying the starter with a side did so sweetly, while the waiter who'd actually served it simply shrugged and walked off. - two for mediocre and not-hot-enough food. This was very disappointing, as I'd been keen to show the place off to my date. Maybe a Saturday afternoon during the January sales wasn't such a good idea. Try in summer when everyone wants to be outside and the Belgo dungeon is less busy!

ZfPrkZUsg8-xhKWX9Wteag.text: What can be said about Belgo that hasn't already been said at length by other Yelpers? It's cheerful, funky, and fun, and if you can pull yourself away right after work, the M-F Beat-The-Clock special is a steal. A nice bowl of mussels and frites for between 5-6 quid is a bargain, and the other beat-the-clock specials (like the veggie tart) are also nice. Add a glass of Hoegaarden Grand Cru or Saison 1900, and it's a perfect casual meal. It's also great for kids, with a filling meal and ice cream for £5. The waiters' costumes are a treat for the kids to watch, too, and the unisex Battlestar Galactica-esque bathroom is fun for kids and adults.

H9zUcPj-2_CRViFGzSkSUQ.text: Superb mussels. Great atmosphere for anyone, including kids.This particular location is awesome since there's lots to do nearby.

Okcs1lPmMqyoMTD-wX5AbQ.text: Went recently after work on a friends recommendation, and thoroughly enjoyed the evening. Huge range of beers on which the staff were very knowledgeable on, so was rude not to sample a few. All delicious, but all around £5 per bottle so can easily add up quickly. Worth it though and did not feel ripped off. Food was equally impressive, opting for the mussels with pancetta, spinach and gruyere cheese I think, with frites, and all in all a thoroughly tasty meal. Will certainly be back to try the beat the clock offering.

XJi4JYEA7ed1Tg27yiOeIg.text: Busy busy busy. Quick service and food doesn't fall below Belgo expectation. Friendly staff. Only doesn't feel as clean as their other restaurant in Camden.Toilets: I don't think it's anything special as some of the other Yelpers have mentioned. There is a foot operated fountain to wash hands which is shared by both sexes...that's it!

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom

yL1BuuGTRUFeh57gSNyxDA.text: We came an hour after opening. This was recommended by Rick Steve's so we were very excited. After ordering, our waitress came back 15 minutes later to tell us they don't have muscles. We were very disappointed that a place famous for muscles didn't have muscles. I wish we would have been told prior to ordering.

gxGIrxh52ukDTa57toQPWQ.text: I booked our company's Christmas dinner here last year, after several people enthusiastically recommended it.Fast forward a couple of months.'Jessica, do you remember that awful meal you booked at Christmas?'Fast forward to me booking another event venue.'Make sure the food is better than that place you booked at Christmas.'Fast forward to any discussion of food in the office.'God, do you remember when you booked at Belgo? That was terrible.'You can't see me, but I'm shaking my fist menacingly in the air, in Belgo Centraal's general direction, because I am never going to live that shit down.

hZfQrTVVhLwvgpnBFuqQ3w.text: Loved it. You Yelpers were spot-on.From the weird, sunken underground trail to the dining rooms to the massive beer selection, to the waitrons in Belgian costume, we had a delicious meal.Bonus: healthy and tasty children's menu plates.

cDza5ykcrS2jndlsLh4rbg.text: I ABSOLUTELY LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE. It combines my three favorite things in the entire world... BEER... MUSSELS... & Frijtes (aka chips/fries).My Family and I came here while we were visiting London and my Dad had heard about Belgo's "BEAT THE CLOCK" special where you pay the price of the time you order... so like if you order at 6:30 you pay £6.30 which is pretty cheap considering!My Father and I both ordered the Mussels & Frijtes and my Mom got the Spit roasted chicken... all three where HUGE portions and absolutely SCRUMPTIOUS.... mmm my mouth is just watering thinking about it now!Because we are all three beer nerds too we just had to order (multiple.... says with a giggle) rounds of beer.... needless to say my mom was uber tipsy by the end of the meal...First Round of Beers:Me: Archel Brune (brewed by Monks, how cool is that?, also really good)Mom: Hoegaarden (white beer... really good)Dad: De Koninck (on tap I think... just ok I thought but Dad loved it)Second Round of Beers:Me: Gulden Draak (mmmmmmm.... yummy I love dark beer!)Mom: Hoegaarden (obviously she liked it enough to order twice)Dad: De Kninck (he like my Mom loved it so much he ordered it again)Desert Round:Me: Floris Framboise (my whole family loved this one with our desert!)Mom: (is a light weight and by this time was to tipsy to order a third...hah)Dad: Floris Honey (not as good as the Raspberry one!)For desert we got a waffle and split it and had a raspberry and honey beer. OMG SOOOO GOOD. Who ever said that beer cannot go with desert was mental.The design of the restaurant was really cool too. As you walk in you can see the chefs firing dishes and then you walk down and your seated in a sort of modern underground beer garden (there is also a sit down restaurant side but who would want to do that?). The loo was also super cool... it was all open and men and women were in the same room though different sides and washed their hands in a ginormous sink.Our server was really nice and the food was hot, fresh and tasty and the beers were great as well. Definitely coming back here the next time I make it down to London.*REMEMBER:-Beat the clock Special!!!-Raspberry fruit beer-Make a reservation because it gets kind of busy-Check out the bathroom (hahaha)

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. The chefs... Part DOS.
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Walking over the chefs to get to the beer garden.
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Out front of of Belgo....

aEJIsMh_HeLh9YLUJqbN1w.text: this was our first restaurant in london. we all thought it was just okay, nothing spectacular but not terrible. it worked for us as it was close to our hotels.keep in mind we didnt try any of the mussels or any of their beers so we probably totally missed the best stuff (we were all jetlagged!)

5z4JhGENgjg7xJ3-REosGQ.text: I've been to Belgium, and this place reminds me more of a German beer hall than a restaurant in Brussels or Antwerp. We decided to make a reservation for the restaurant rather than sit at the huge tables in the dining hall. The prices were rather high--even for London--and the food was just average. I wanted mussels, but they were out of them. Who ever heard of a Belgian restaurant specializing in mussels being out of them on a Wednesday evening? The Belgian beer selection was just OK--I expected some rare, highly rated Belgian brews like Westie (Westvleteren ale) on the menu and yes, I know it's hard to get but this place has the money to track some down. However, not to be totally negative, this is a fun place to meet up with friends if you are in London and well-located with Covent Garden and Soho pubs nearby.

kTLkhxywWfM-FX9QoWVArQ.text: It's a tricky thing to review a restaurant when all you've had is their cheapie 8 quid special, but as far as that goes, you'll walk out fairly satisfied here at Belgo.  By far the best choice is the chili sauce half chicken, which is exactly that, a huge half hen all plump and juicy, served with quite fantastic belgian fries.  The fries do resemble those I had in Belgium, halfway between the shoestring style and not at all the British wedge cut or homestlye fry, ( also unlike what the americans think Belgium fries should look like.)  All that served with a half of lager, by far the most boring brew served here but for the price the whole ensemble delivers well enough. The steak is a sad little tough cut, so don't do that.But enough about the food, who are you kidding, you go here for the ale, right?  Belgian Ale kick all sorts of ass, and they have the twenty page beer menus here.. none cheap, but most start at 6% and destroy most of the otherwise boring crap you find in pubs in the area.  My Brugse Zot on wasn't as amazing as I remembered it in Brugge, but it hit the spot.Oh yeah, the waitstaff walk around in trappist robes which kind of lends an odd cultist look to them, but their little symbols imprinted dead center of their chests kind of look like Decepticon logos, and in that light it' a neat little cross-cultural twist.

rugVGAdxzmpKunljOh1HYg.text: We use to love going here one in a while, especially for the lobsters. Admittedly we haven't been here for a couple of years. So when we got to the restaurant to find out our favourite surf and turf dish was off the menu I was immediately a little disppointed but we continued anyway.I ordered rib eye steak and my wife ordered the 'Snob', mussels cooked in lobster bique with fried. The steak was quite soft and tender but everything else was poor. The fries were not hot, the lobster bisque was a watery soup that didn't really taste like a bisque but the biggest problem was the amount of MSG or artificial flavouring they now use - we were so thirsty. The next morning I was absolutely gasping for water.If there is a positive, the atmosphere is excellent, really noisy and ideal for large parties. The beer selection is very good but everything else has gone down hill.

k-F-1PwQJvt6qQFb7SIT2A.text: After climbing the 2,038 steps from the base of the Covent Garden tube station and ascending into the "part of the world" Ariel wanted to join so much, I was exhausted. And starving. And sweaty. But mostly starving. My brother and I met up with a friend from high school who's living in London and she recommended Belgo Centraal so we walked 2 blocks, scanned the menu, and descended back into the dark world from which we just came.Turns out Belgo is German-Biergarten-meets-French-cuisine-meets-Medieval-Times.   With a menu full of mussels, beers, duck and roasted chicken, anyone should be able to find something to meet their pan-European palette. We had a few mess ups with our drink orders (white wine instead of red, beers we didn't order but gladly drank), but our food came out as ordered and in great time. I went with the Wild Boar sausages with Belgian stoemp mash & berry jus. Everything was flavorful, well cooked and wonderfully presented. I ate every last drop.Cool find with a diverse menu. Would gladly come back the next time I'm on that side of the pond.

fbFqm8cjHnWSXIB2aoBZ0w.text: Cold, undercooked skirt steak masquerading as a tbone was mostly grizzle. My friends mussel platter was mostly empty shells. Frites  appeared to be fresh from an American sack of ore-ida frozen. Sad meal...

OMDeMUZL6-Nw4wV0U6nRSA.text: Massive fan of Belgos, especially their beat the clock offer.  Love the beer and I don't ordinarily drink it.  Love the atmosphere and the fact that the waiters are dressed up in I don't even know what - monks?  Just love it, can't explain why.  You just need to go and delve into the mussels and garlic, it's divine!

xByQFBnZIqCQ_OcRS7ZuhA.text: I quite enjoyed my meal here. I wasn't overwhelmed by anything in particular but if you're not completely unfed an order of mules-frites and a starter/side is quite satisfactory for two.You enter into the restaurant via a dark but futuristic style tunnel to be greeted by a woman with one of those head set microphones conferring with the waiting staff downstairs about availability (which there was lots so I don't quite understand our long wait under curved corrugated steel and tubular lighting), the interior decor is, well, interesting. When you finally venture down into what looks like a would be medieval dungeon -especially given the waiters knight-style dress- it appears to have been confused with an industrially retrofitted nuclear bunker. Nothing wrong with this but just so you know...We ordered the croquettes (note- there are two croquettes only, the minimum on a plate to enable the use of a plural here) with a sort of limp side salad. We went for the Thai style mussels, which wasn't spicy at all, (that that concerns you either way), just a coriander, coconut milky sort of marinade which would have been great for bread dipping (note to self about obtaining a bread basket next time).Impressive selection of beers at mostly reasonable prices, which I would definitely venture back to try more of. When the bill came I'm delighted to say we had something called "Mussel Madness" scrawled on the end which was a deduction of a few pounds (maybe 10%? I'm not sure what or how much but thank you Belgos!) so I can't complain about that! Next note to self- it was a Monday maybe that's the madness day...

I42xDCN5oVN5CxnoHysT6w.text: I like this place feels like a industrial Soho place one floor down in the underground. Place is simple cheap and vibrant. Mussels are not good at all, actually very bad(belive me it not so hard do cook mussels), the starter and dessert was great actually.

Ve69xxTvmp4WweqrMmL9SQ.text: Who likes mussels?I like mussels! I love mussels in fact!Belgium is not a country that fills me with joy (trip to Antwerp in my first year of uni, Antwerp really wasn't the new Capital if Fashion that I was promised. Didn't see much fashion but did see heroin needles in the street, a man pissing in a plant pot in the middle of a shopping centre and a small dog pulling poo out of it's own butt!), but Belgo's has vastly improved my opinion of this country. I don't know if I would want to go back to Belgium, but I keep going back to Belgo's.Each of my three visits has been really different, but good times were had by all on each of them. Different dishes, different locations of the restaurant and varying times of the day, so I really feel like a Belgo connoisseur.Visit 1. Late night evening meal after much boozing with my ladies.Got to sit in side bunker area, all dark and atmospheric, thought the waiter in his strange giant rubber apron get up was from a horror film and was coming to kill us. Moules Florentine and frites were to die for. I think I actually licked the plate.Visit 2. Early evening civilised eats after work.Good food, good service, good friends. Tried the Moules Portuguese. Nice, tomato-y, new potatoes, healthy option. Bit sad to have just missed the beat the clock offer, but food here is always worth the full price money.Visit 3. Day date for my birthday.Had goat cheese salad (just to be a bit different). Nice and tasty. The man (who is a massive talker and is very rarely ever silent) was so in love with his food he became mute (until the plate was scraped clean, then the talking was back on!). Fishcakes and duck and a variety of different beers all got the thumbs up from him.Coffees finished it all off nicely, but felt service was a little lacking this once.So it's official. Belgo's rocks my world. Loves the food, loves the drinks and love, love loves the building, urban metal and brick tunnels and school type benches to sit on really make this place stand out.

NiwkmpRuUgFiNVZHr14uzQ.text: Most people find my descriptions of Belgo to be fabricated fantasies born of an overactive imagination:1) the bathroom is uni-sex and the communal faucet is like a fountain!2) all the servers are dressed like monks!3) you pay based on what time of day it is!Right-o.However, I will say that Belgo is a pretty A+ place to bring out-of-town visitors and faboo for group outtings. The novelty of the restaurant is sure to charm your companions and the beer selection is eggggggcellent. Now that they've got a loyalty card, expect me to show up more often.Mmm mussels and beer (I initialy wrote this as "muscles and beer", haha oh ME!)

_z9YubpxccpQMXb4qxMK6A.text: great mussels with reasonable price...the lobster  is also good but a bit expensive...

QhiGeHYt8RPSq5ztDLa3BQ.text: Holy cow. Everything about this place was delicious. From the mussels to the chips to the beers to the waffles.You will not regret going here if you like any of the above.

oxGSCiejOzdzYcC-uXX5hw.text: When I told people I was going to London their replies ranged from, "Ooh, maybe you'll meet a hot British guy" (didn't happen) to, "I bet you won't want to come back" (I did), to, "I hear they're snaggleteeth there" (no comment), and "Oh, the food there is terrible, just eat Indian food all the time" (I did not).  By my second day in London I was less concerned with my food options and more concerned with how easily the pounds were flying out of my wallet like I was trying to make it rain.  While taking in Covent Gardens one day, I consulted my tourist beacon aka guidebook and found a nearby restaurant serving two of my favorite things: seafood and Belgian beer.  To top it off they offered an Express Lunch: a lager, a house wine or soft drink, moules (mussels) and frites (Really? Do I need to translate?) for £7.5.  Granted, £7.5 is still over $11 since apparently the British are still punishing us for jumping ship centuries ago, but I could happily delude myself into thinking it was $7.50.  Now I knew I would be able to eat in Paris later that week and not have to volunteer to be someone's African nanny for the day!My eyes danced the entire time I was at Belgo: the servers dress like Belgian monks, the walls are lined with kegs and kegs of delicious Belgian beer (I believe they have a variety of hundreds.  HUNDREDS, people!) and I loved the industrial interior.  Even the bathroom was an experience - it was co-ed and there wasn't much dividing the male and female sides and you share a sink.  I was a bit slow on the uptake so when I saw a dude walk by me I was ready to bust out some self defense moves 'cause I will cut a mofo who gets to close to me and my lady business uninvited.  But, all was well, he belonged there.  I asked our Dutch-looking server if I could take a photo of her and her uniform - she gave me a strange look, which being in London I couldn't decipher whether it meant, "I don't speak very good English," "Bitch, WTF?", or "Idiot American traitors!"  I explained to her, squirming in my dorkiness, that I'm someone who likes to take photos of her surroundings to capture the moment and she then bashfully acquiescedThe traditionnelle mussels were tasty.  They were delivered in a steaming pot seasoned with white wine, celery, onion and garlic.  Accompanying them were the fries and a side of mayo (of course).  I left Belgo satiated, less poor than I feared, happily tipsy and ready to go to Belgium for a love affair with a brewery.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Part of the beer menu

zKyQJC77WoD5JV4S5Q1P6A.text: I prefer the camden one. Only because I hate bench seating. There was a lunch deal on fries and mussels with a beverage. I've had mussels at a few different places and have never had so many closed and broken ones. but they probably make them in large batches for all the people doing the lunch deal. oh well, deals a deal.

cOsFaBIBkkDsowTsAiwjkA.text: Cracking place. Don't expect high gourmet food and you will not be disappointed. That does not mean the food is bad...it's great. You go downstairs to a modern cellar, benches and tables. It's all open plan making the atmosphere very friendly. I have been many times with friends and the service has nearly always been fast. I don't eat seafood but have tried a few mussels and they were nice (big portions every time). I have tried the pork belly, duck, steak and sausages at various times. They are all great. Never had anyone come along who didn't enjoy it.HINT; women love Belgian beer. The goblets are small enough to try a few but I strongly recommend the Chimay Bleu...three glasses and you feel a bit giggly and stoned. Also, hit a rack of the Schnapps. I am smiling just thinking about Belgo. It is one of the most consistently reliable eating places in town, and I know...I AM A LONDONER.

HDGTGPOF35zjqG3fVXcwMQ.text: It's a good place.  Food is decent.  Great range of beers.  Trouble is, it's just too big.  Lots of staff but still seemingly understaffed.  The food could have been incredible but when three of every five orders arrive.... one of five you need to chase up, and the other either doesn't show up or comes an hour late.I'm sure it's fine during the week but if you come on a weekend evening, don't expect decent service.  Next time I'll go to Holborn or Chalk Farm.

PS4SsZBZMGuGwix928LQ0g.text: Really great, even though I am the opposite of a mussel fan!  The food is executed quite well, they have a fantastic bar, and the industrial decor is great.  Love the fruit beers!

iLFxukVYnXQt45oyvsXAJQ.text: Belgo Centraal was surprisingly busy for a weekday lunch! After a while, we (me and my girly friends Angharad and Sarah) were guided downstairs to the underground restaurant, and seated at our table. The rumours we true: the waiters are Trapiste Monks (ok, not real ones, but still: mighty cool). I didn't get a photo of it, but they also had a CAGE OF BEER. You have to see it to believe it. We chose light lunches from their express lunch menu (one main meal plus Cristal beer/house wine/soft drink, £7.95 a head). Angharad was taking it easy with a goat's cheese salad and a water, Sarah went for the beef carbonnade and a coke, and I chose the spit roast chicken with chilli and ginger sauce, and I had a Cristal (they wouldn't let me substitute it for a kriek, and I even offered to pay more!!). We made a valiant effort  Angharad was pleasantly surprised by her salad (that goat's cheese looks delicious), Sarah used her beef carbonnade as a dipping sauce for chips, and I ate nearly all of my chicken.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom

EvycO6KFbTtLoP3Yyf1dTw.text: I really should've been studying at home that day, but somehow I ended up having a full day in London, taking la family from HK to see my two uni campuses and also venture into the wellcome museum. Anyways, my family LOVE seafood and I thought what's one place that's a bit unusual. And I had initially wanted to go the belgian mini UYE but decided to work on essay but obviously, that plan flew SO far out the window. So i dragged my family instead.The entrance was unusual, by that I mean, the lights on the floor bake you. It's the new thing. The reception is pretty much an alleyway in the building, and the actual seating areas are downstairs in the basement where men in dress robes will be waiting for you. It's okay, it's not about to get super weird. I promise.You're in a Belgian restaurant, it's got kegs everywhere. BEER O CLOCK. :) We decided to try the Passionfruit one, it's really sweet. More like a sparkling juice. (okay, more like COCKTAIL O CLOCK, but who's checking....) We ordered two pot of 1 kg mussels to share between the 8 of us. Classic and Traditional (with Cream). They were really delicious, the classic one was the best out of the two. I feel like there should've been a bit more seasoning with the cream but it went well with the double cooked frites. We also ordered the pan fried lamb and pan fried duck. Cooked to perfection. Pink in the middle. WIN. The beef stew my brother ordered was a bit sweet, but it was very rich. We also ordered garlic mussels and a seafood stew which were also very fresh. The former was a bit oily, I wish I ordered the one with lobster bisque now. :) I can't remember what else we ordered but we were so full even without dessert. It was also around £150 for about 8 of us. less than £20 per person inc. service charge. score. The place was buzzing on a tuesday evening, pretty much filled up when we left, so it's a rather popular place. Apparently, lots of hot girls according to the brothers and cousin. Bit disturbing whilst I'm eating but if you're there for good food and uh. girls. I'd  highly recommend it.P.S: I do realise my review has everything a man wants. beer, food, girls.....

8iFi-h6WdnItpHZPCCheZA.text: Belgo Central is a great location right at the heart of Covent Garden serving Belgian food mainly mussels and lots of Belgian Beer. We reserved the place for 6.15 but most of us turned up at 6.40 but still this was OK which is a little surprising, it didn't take too long midweek on a Wednesday evening. We got served almost immediately with the drinks and the food arrived after about 20 minutes which was reasonable. The great thing overall is that they have revamped the menu, instead of just mussels with cream, they now serve lobster or Japanese crumbs  or other various sauces. I had the cod burger and it was cooked very nicely throughout and the frites were also quite good. For the Belgian beer, I had the Brugse Zot Brute, not sure what it means but it was recommended by the waiter and it was a very good choice. The beer wasn't too string and it tasted fruity as well as an ale, it was fantastic, not too fizzy. All in all, the new serving Belgo is better than before.

photos.caption: Photo of Belgo Centraal - London, United Kingdom. Cod Burger with frites + Half Lobster

8MJsc1RiLJLU2rqWdgP7Cg.text: We discovered the secret to a great night at Belgo.  Well, there is no secret, the food is good so it'd be great anytime.  But to have a REALLY great night on the cheap - go on a Monday!!  Since the theatre district is relatively dead on Mondays, they offer this amazing deal, presumably to get more business.  Any mussel dish (yes, any) and a drink (house wine, house wheat, house pils, or a coke/lemonade/etc) for £10.  Yes, £10.  I don't know how they do it, but they do, and it's an amazing deal.  Hard to find a better meal for cheaper!Downstairs there's a restaurant bit and a more lively bar bit, so you can decide where you want to sit.  You'll walk past the big, noisy kitchen and it's fun to see all the plates of mussels lined up.  There's also a lobster tank, so you can wave hello and goodbye to your dinner (or somebody else's.)  We all got the mussel deal - I got the espagnole which was mussels with chorizo, potato, and tomato.  Gorgeous!  They were cooked perfectly, and the sausage was abundant - I even pawned some off on my boyfriend as couldn't finish it all.  We ordered some bread as well, for about £3, so we could use it to mop up the sauce - there will be a lot of sauce left at the bottom!  You can pick fries or salad with the mussels.  Obviously you should get fries, but you get quite a lot of them so my mom got fries and I got a salad and we shared.  The salad was actually pretty good and had some surprise ingredients like edamame on it.  The fries were lovely and addictive.  Everyone loved their mussels - the Thai ones were very popular among my mom and boyfriend.  We ate and ate and just stuffed ourselves.  The wheat beer, which I had as my drink, was a bit unusual.  Sort of citrus tasting, significantly so.  But not bad, just a bit strongly flavored.  So if you like that sort of thing, it's right up your street.Go on a Monday, eat abundantly for cheap, and be darn pleased with yourself.  Great place to go with friends or a date, though it is a bit noisy!

Yx_MBHz0Y_8Jy-hE8oETfw.text: Highly recommended place with great Belgian good and an impressive selection of fine Belgian beers. The underground location is really hip and well decorated. Will be back next time I'm in London.

Iv2EMaQCs28BB-P_fjWHuw.text: Went to Belgo today with a group of friends (11 in total), and all of us had Time out vouchers, whuch allowed us to have a kilo pot of mussels, fries and a beer or prosecco for £10. A voucher did not specify neither the amount of beer or the type, which caused a slight tension. The waitress brought us half a pint of Leffe and said that is all we get. We quickly did the maths and the value of the meal did not up to a voucher value...

vPs2sLHT4PCqnRa71DjAKg.text: A recent UYE saw a motley crew of Yelpers club on down to Belgo Centraaaaaaal for some moules-frites - Belgian style! Nice place is Belgo Centraaaaaaaaaal, looking a little like a 1980s vision of the future, well, the upstairs at least, while downstairs, once you descend the stairs and pass through a rather innocuous looking door, is a room which I expected to be larger than it actually was. Communal seating is the biggest order in this Belgian basement, they'll cram you in somewhere in amongst these long tables.I mentioned Belgian style moules-frites but I, perhaps feeling contrary, opted for Thai style (who knew I'd find that here?). And as it turned out, they were quite nice though I would have liked more chips/frites than I received.I found the service a little haphazard. I needed to remind one waiter that my drink hadn't arrived when I ordered it about 20 minutes prior while another waiter was providing us with parts of our cutlery midway through the meal. All the staff I dealt with appeared keen and friendly but, perhaps, not the most diligent.Also, a number of the staff wear what look an awful lot like cassocks but do not provide any explanation or apparent reasoning behind this decision. I quite like this.All in all, this is a decent place. A place one is not likely to be terribly disappointed with but, at the same time, a place which is unlikely to ever wow you.I don't know the Flemish for 'meh'.Ian

yZaOGjBkslK_XCb6s6He_g.text: Restaurant with great ambience and select mussels and comfort food. The place was packed when we arrived, lots of people waiting, but we did not have a reservation so did not mind waiting the 10-15 minutes. We had the cod burger and provencale musseles, both were top notch. i would go back.

T7YnuwXC-EfUn86jmkd3Rg.text: These place in the earthintense my world. I like the concept of their foodand love's it, also loves the drinks and love, loveTheircentral seating areais in the lower level and its canteen-style with its long tables & benches.Their servers are dressed as a monk. The beams have hooks so you can hang yourcoats. The lighting is dim, and the ambiance is lively and boisterous. I likethe most the mongozo banana beer that was so exotic and excitingto the non-beerdrinker in me that I wanted to try all the fruity beers on the list of optionsand then some. The mussels were above regular, so much so that I'm nowinterested in returning for some of the more inspired varieties on theirmenu. Mussels are their specialty. Allin all, it is very cool and fantastic!!!

ry-t3YOfIgmW_F6AWcVAjg.text: Belgo's is the best for mussels, frites, Belgian beers, schnapps and waiters dressed like monks! The mussels and frites are really satisfying and it is a pretty casual and affordable restaurant with a  fun industrial vibe. I was really impressed with the service when we had a group of three the waiter very kindly asked if we could move tables because they had a big party coming in, which was totally fine but to apologize he gave us a giant stick of schnapps shots and took one with us. I was very impressed with that level of service and it was cool to take a shot with someone dressed  like a monk :)

MJdXdo7xH_AaNvsHCcrAGQ.text: Absolute worst service ever!  Our table was managed by Bahtka and if shes yours try to move to another table immediately.  One of our party didn't care for the beer she ordered and when asked for another selection she responded as if our friend was ignorant for asking in the first place.  Overall the five of us just sat back and marveled at the utter lack of competency or attention to customers we have all ever seen in our life!  Food?  Pretty darn good across the board and for the eats alone would sorta recommend on that alone..

29TpMLOfPDDq4K11sLhMOw.text: The descent down into this place makes you feel as if you are being transported into an underworld metallic broiler room.  It is crazy.  It was an outer world experience.  The servers are also dressed in black monk like robes, which adds to the outer world experience. I should have asked what that was all about. You are seated.  The place is VERY loud.  Which I am cool with, but be  prepared. This is not a place to go for a romantic evening out.  It is a lively and energetic place.  It is a Belgian Mussel and beer focused menu.  The mussels and frites were to die for.  You can't go wrong.  Definitely would come back!

AiGTBAQCsHL4jrqoozYk5Q.text: We had a small UYE here yesterday so was excited to go back to Belgo Centraal after a long break. The menu is interesting and has many tempting options so clearly well thought out. I decided to order the classic  moules + frites but with an interesting sounding champagne and lobster sauce. The food came fairly quickly and the moules themselves were pretty good: smooth and cooked just to the right level and very clean. The sauce was pretty good and well flavoured and did indeed have a good lobster taste. Had to ask for a spoon two times for the soupy moules sauce. Why wouldn't they provide a spoon I wonder since no one else seemed to get one either?The frites weren't really Belgian Frites, they were frozen chips which is not the same thing at all and tasted like the fries you get at any fast food joint. ie pretty boring so have to deduct a point for that.Had to ask for Frite sauce (took two attempts). In the past they used to provide that with the frites which I remember being proper frites and so better than this. My request for the sauce was met with some uncertainty and the waiter thought I wanted so clearly not a regular request so bought a mini pot of standard mayo.Beer was good since you can't really go wrong with Belgian beer, especially the bottled varieties which are usually excellent and they have a good range with decent descriptions.Service was a little haphazard and intermittent and does feel a bit like a production line, as others have mentioned. In terms of value,  again A-OK. Not cheap but then the quality A-OK also.The subterranean brick vault / industrial vibe works well and for a spot to go for informal lunch or dinner in Covent garden, it's a good choice.My last two visits to the Chalk farm branch, Belgo Noord were so much better all around and seems like the centraal branch doesn't have to try so hard since with the central location in crowded Covent Garden there is often a queue outside so go with mid expectations and you will be satisfied.

a4IzSQC46y6MS1H8i-0xIw.text: Great spot if you're into sea food. I personally don't care much for seafood but the wifey munched down on all she could order. On the positive side beer was great as well as the atmosphere, highly recommend

ivV5vlOYxLX-pajRKL1NRQ.text: Can you give 0 stars? If I could I would.  If you're looking for good food, nice service, and a good atmosphere, with non creepy bathrooms Belgo is not the place for you. Their specialty of mussels were watery and tasteless and the frites were no better than mcdonalds.  The spare ribs were inedible and even the mashed potatoes were bad.  And even pasta which one should not be able to mess up was not good.  The servers were inattentive and surly.  Don't believe the hype avoid this place like the plague. Especially when in London there are hundreds of wonderful restaurants.

t_tn0a-f7OkXqE1nYmi3Hw.text: Huge choice of delicious mussels and beer. The beer menu is actually larger than the food menu! Great atmosphere, although can be very noisy - the waiters are dressed as monks.

SwE7ZHiDdnaTCljevDmG6A.text: The mussels in the thai sauce are absolutely scrumptious and the special offer at lunchtime is a great idea. I love the bread it is so tasty and the seating plan gives it an ambiance out on its own.

D1bOKI3x4zCbR_JqVd9C5w.text: Fantastic restaurant. The waiters are dressed as Belgian monks. Great food and beers. Children eat free.

0SuorgTDeijLyVU4Gql8zw.text: I was recommended this establishment by a friend who raved about it so I decided to go there for supper. Got there at about 8pm on a Wednesday to find it was packed to the rafters with a 45 minute waiting time. Promising but I'm not the sort to wait in a queue so I left and returned the following Saturday at lunchtime. Again, it was busy but my party was quickly shown a table. The atmosphere is allegedly Belgian- I've done Brussels a few times and quite frankly it was little more than a caricature; priests' habits? Please! Nontheless, service was punctual and polite and the menu had a reasonable selection although our vegetarian struggled to find something appealing in a very limited vegetarian selection. Two of us went for the excellent value Express Lunch (choice of main dish from four dishes and a beer for £7.99. Mine, Mussels and chips was fine but not sensational, but Mrs L's meat was gristly although tasty. Many of the Belgian beers are frankly potty - strawberry flavour anyone? - but the list is extensive with something for everyone. In all, the experience was good, not too expensive and quick enough to satisfy the hardcore shoppers in the group. On a final note, the industrial design theme (lots of metal, pipes, etc) gave it a modern and quirky feel which the kids enjoyed. Would I go again? Probably not, but worth trying at least the once; you never know, you might like the taste of Belgian beer!
